summary: A clash between good and evil awaits as young Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson) prepare for a final battle against Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes). Harry has grown into a steely lad on a mission to rid the world of evil. The friends must search for the Horcruxes that keep the dastardly wizard immortal. Harry and Voldemort meet at Hogwarts Castle for an epic showdown where the forces of darkness may finally meet their match.

An excellent end to this franchise. From the moment the opening music starts, you know that this is going to be very different from how the franchise started. This final instalment neatly wraps up many of the seeming contradictions in the storyline that were in the earlier parts of the story. Not the best movie in the series in my opinion, but nonetheless extremely enjoyable. There are a few parts that still raise more questions than answers, but these do not spoil the overall storyline, and the sequence of events around the Elder wand is not particularly convincing - more a Scooby Doo explanation than Hercule Poirot. The final ending is quite funny as the actors have not been made to look old enough for the roles in the very final scenes.  Unlike many multi part stories that have an unsatisfactory ending, this is a must watch once you have seen the rest.

This is the wizarding world's epic stuff at its best. Nothing greater than the feeling and sensation of an entire creative and heart-filled franchise coming to one awesome conclusion! The only thing wrong with this movie is that it's kind of forgettable only at the beginning, and doesn't really get perfect until Harry, Hermione, and Ron enter Hogwarts for the final big battle. After that, so many flawless movie scenes (when astounding plot-twisting truths are revealed, when Harry and Dumbledore are in Limbo, when Neville gives his speech and kills the snake, when Harry finally kills Voldemort, when they're at King's Cross Station in the epilogue to wrap it all up perfectly with even the little detail of the chocolate frog as a call back to the first movie), just brilliant stuff! This was even better than Avengers Endgame imo! All of the Harry Potter movies are good/great/awesome, and it ended as epically well-done as it could!

The Harry Potter saga tells us about the adventures of the young magic and sorcery apprentice Harry Potter and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley, during the years they spend at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, who spends his life training to defeat the enemy voldemort, in my opinion, the story is very good, the special effects are great and the characters are really good since they interpret it in the best way. In my personal impression, the saga is very good, since I really like magic, and the characters that come out are played by actors and actresses that I really like. A recommendation that I would give him would be that they had not made so many films, since some are filler.

Wow, this is all I can really say after viewing this climatic and powerfully acted finale to the decade long Harry Potter franchise!  Truly epic in every sense of the word, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows- Part 2" is a stunning and powerful achievement!  I don't think a better conclusion to such a beloved and magical series could have been obtained by changing anything in this film!  From start to finish the film is relentless, much like Lord Voldemort and the film's 2+ running time flies by in the blink of an eye.  We finally learn and accept the fates of all our characters and what their legacy is.  My favorite character throughout (Alan Rickman as Professor Snape) is finally justified and his childhood examined, giving tremendous insight and emotional pull to his actions.  During his final moments I was literally in tears knowing how hard his life was and the darkness he had to endure and yet in the end he was always a wonderful person at his core!  Not only was I emotionally devastated throughout the film but I was so thoroughly engaged that I could not take my eyes away for even the slightest moment.  The film brings together everything that made this wonderful franchise such a huge hit and brings it to the ultimate climax, deciding the fate of everyone good and bad in the process.  The impeccable special effects, wonderfully developed characters, stunning sets of the various settings, and all around general epic feel that I desired was given to me.  I could not be more happy with how it all turned out, however I shed many tears along the way especially when it came to Professor Snape and his sacrifices.  I cannot recommend this enough, although most have already seen most if not all the films, if you haven't you owe it to yourself.  You will not be disappointed!

Here it is, a cinematic event to rival them all, the epic conclusion to one of the greatest franchises of the cinema. And what a grand finale it is. The end of Harry Potter's adventure is not just one of the very best entries in the saga, it's also one of the very best films of the summer. Thrilling, tragic, funny, touching, and--most importantly--magical, it's a film that ties up loose ends, reveals some surprises, and delivers a ride that takes you across the emotional spectrum. Director David Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves by now have a firm hand on the material and deftly move us from the solemn opening to a teary-eyed finale. The pace here is unlike most any Potter film, probably since this is the most action-packed one yet. Spirited chases, an episode with a dragon, and rousing one-on-one battles are enough to get your blood pumping, and the dazzling visuals (often brought to life by the 3D) put you in the middle of the action. But what has given this series its juice is the cast of actors, young and old, who have brought these beloved characters to vivid life. Almost all get their moment to shine, although that crammed roster (dead characters also make appearances) can trip up the momentum the film has going for itself. But sensing the end, everyone commits to their parts with a heartfelt flourish. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson are the heart and soul of the series, and have grown up with it. Seeing them wholly inhabit Harry, Ron, and Hermione's last stage in their emotional journey is one of the great movie going pleasures of recent memory. The other young men and women deliver the goods as well. Not to mention the elder thespians, who are superb, one and all. Michael Gambon, Ralph Fiennes, Alan Rickman (especially terrific), Robbie Coltrane, John Hurt, Gary Oldman, Jason Issacs, David Thewlis, Julie Walters, Mark Williams, Jim Broadbent, Emma Thompson, Imelda Staunton, Warwick Davis, and best of all, my personal favorite, the regal Maggie Smith. The two new additions to cast are Ciaran Hinds and the great Kelly McDonald, and they leave sharp impressions. Everything comes together in such a satisfying way it's really hard to see where the story could go from here, despite what potential the "next generation" epilogue offers. Over the course of seven books, eight films, and ten years, we've gone on a magical adventure with a great hero to a world both wonderfully enchanting and humanly recognizable, and we've been happy to go along and lose ourselves to the magic of it all

Magical, wonderful, beautiful, magical, action packed, mysterious, magical again!! I am just absolutely beyond words. This incredible journey has taken me to places that nobody has ever been to, and even though these seven incredible adventures have scared me to death, it has been a blast getting to know the characters, the story, the magical creatures that make you feel more alive,……….darn! I can't think of anything else to say. But still, in spite of all the dangers that came throughout the adventure, I still had an absolute blast. This experience is something that I will never forget, especially when it comes to flying a broomstick every single day, or creating random potions at Professor Snape's classroom. I'm sorry. I keep getting ahead of myself. What I'm trying to say is that this is a story that every single person out there should get their hands on. Yet, even though its hard to say goodbye to these incredible characters until next time, HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS: PART 2 brings in multiple opportunities for those that want to be witches, wizards, and incredible adventurers in the years to come. I am forever grateful to be a part of this incredible journey in the one place that everybody wants to go to: The Wizarding World of Harry Potter. J.K. Rowling, thank you.

As the finale of the entire Harry Potter series, what 10 years of joy and heartbreak has been building up to, it's hard to imagine a much more satisfying conclusion than what is shown in Deathly Hallows Part 2.
I will admit, it does have its flaws here and there. There are a couple plot holes, lines of dialogue that reference book related material that was never placed in the movies, and an ending twist that kind of soured some of this movie's good will towards the end. But, still, those mean next to nothing to just how fantastic this movie is!
The characters are great, the music is a surprising high point of the film, the pacing quick while never feeling rushed, the action is awesome, the stakes are high, and the emotional moments hit hard.  
It's a flawed but marvelous finale to one of the best and most famous franchises in history, and (arguably) pulls off the biggest accomplishment of any ending: it tops everything that came before it.

Warning: Spoilers
I have enjoyed all the films and love the books, and after how much I loved Deathly Hallows Part 1 this entry, continuing from exactly where the previous film left off, had a lot to live up to. It is less faithful to the mammoth but very interesting and wonderful book than its predecessor. However I found this, apart from one or two disjointed parts where you could tell that details had been left out and the arrival in Hogsmede and the duel between Mrs Weasley and Bellatrix seemed a little rushed, had more flow, was better paced and had more coherent storytelling and less of admiring the scenery than the previous entries.

What stood out for me was not only the darkness of it, particularly the last thirty minutes or so which was a tad anti-climatic but very intense too and also Snape's death, but also the emotional impact. Gringotts(especially for the effects, the dragon being the standout), the moving Ressurrection stone sequence and Harry's final scene with Dumbedore were very well done, but my favourite was the Snape's memory sequence, which was beautifully done and quite poignant. Not only that, it's my favourite Harry Potter scene alongside the Three Brothers animated sequence and the Cave Scene. The 19 Years Later scene was quite affectionate as well, with the use of the original music and all.

Once again, the production values are impeccable. The effects, apart from the odd ropey one in the Room of Requirement scene and Bellatrix's death, are excellent particularly at Gringotts, while the scenery and cinematography are magical with a touch of austerity too, and David Yates delivers his best directing job. There's also my favourite of Alexandre Desplat's scores, I loved his ones for Girl with a Pearl Earring and The King's Speech, the score was also one of the few good points about Twilight:New Moon and I found his score for the previous part very effective. What I loved though about this score was not just how beautiful, haunting and how incredibly melancholic it was, but also how much it enhanced the drama.

The script is very good a vast majority of the time, doing a noble attempt to stick to the spirit of the book. The humour is less stilted and corny than I can find it to be, and when the tone is tense and poignant the writing does an above decent job reflecting that. The pacing is never dull, if deliberately less rushed(Goblet of Fire) or glacial(Deathly Hallows Part 1) as some of the other entries, and the storytelling is always interesting and compelling while never convoluted.

The acting is very good. Rupert Grint is great as he consistently is, Emma Watson while not quite as good as she was in Deathly Hallows Part 1 gives one of her better performances of the series, Maggie Smith and John Hurt are always good value and while I didn't find him easy to warm to at first until Half-Blood Prince in his brief but relevant appearance Michael Gambon is also good. Helena Bonham-Carter, David Thewlis, Gary Oldman, Robbie Coltrane and Tom Felton while neither are at their best here bring a pleasing sheen to the film. Three actors in particular I found stood out and gave their best performances of the series. One is Daniel Radcliffe, at first I found him likable yet wooden with some questionable delivery, however overtime I think he's grown with more emotional range than usual. Two is Alan Rickman, while I have considered him one of the more consistent actors of this series him and the character of Snape really shine here, Rickman is especially good in the Snape's memory sequence. Three is Ralph Fiennes, I think it helps that like Snape Voldemort is given more scope here, that said Fiennes is appropriately sinister in the role and certainly looks the part.

In conclusion, a wonderful film and for me the best of the series. And I still stand by my initial feeling that it was better filming the book as two movies, it would've have felt far too rushed as one. 9/10 Bethany Cox.

The final film in the series certainly delivers in terms of spectacle - and not a small amount of darkness despite the need to tie it up with an appropriate ending. The final revelations of Rowling's brilliantly conceived world show a view of good and evil, and the place of people in a world that is both, as more subtle and nuanced than many of the fantasy/science-fiction epics. It's all a bit too long and overblown, but the skill of the world-building is palpable - it's always a place people will want to return to, a set of characters we'll want to spend time with.

Even though it's the shortest in runtime in the franchise, I was basically glued to the TV the entire time. I sensed so much urgency in Harry and could not be more invested in him and his allies. 

The ending did not disappoint and delivered plenty explosion, wizardry, and valor from the characters. Everyone united and faced the strong and desperate dark lord himself. It was glorious. 

Overall, a magnificent way to end the franchise. I enjoyed almost every installment, but this one for sure delivered all aspects. 9.5/10

Harry Potter is a series of films about the fight against evil wizards, released since 2001 and based on the books of the English writer J. K. Rowling. The film consists of 10 parts in the fantasy genre, which received 8 nominations in the award. 
    The plot with each part is both exciting and terrifying. On his 11th birthday, Harry learns of his magical powers. He and his friends are destined to fight against evil wizards. In each part of the film, new acquaintances and adventures are added, taking place in the magical school of Hogwarts. 
    The acting is amazing, spectacular and brilliant. The film's biggest stars are Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson. As for the special effects, they are absolutely incredible. 
    All in all, Harry Potter is one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. It is the most outstanding film in the history of cinema. You shouldn't miss it!
The conclusion of the Harry Potter saga is one of the greatest finales of all existing movie franchises.
A great follow up for Deathly Hallows Part 1. The battle scenes were beautifully done, it has the greatest plot twist ever, and a great way to bring the franchise to an end!!!!

An excellent conclusion to the Harry Potter book to movie series. Top notch CGI in special effects for the movie. The one 1/2 down-grade I gave it was actually due to the final duel scene with Harry & Voldemort, right after Neville Longbottom kills Voldemort's snake, Nagini, with the Sword of Griffindor. The simple cracking of Voldemort's face and then scattering away in the wind in tiny pieces was a complete slap in the face to audiences that deserved a MUCH more intense demise after following this movie series for 10 years. Lets face it, if we started our kids on the first movie at age six, they would have been sixteen when the last installment was released. I'm fairly confident they could have handled a more severe send-off to one of the screen's most hated characters. Did anyone in the theater you attended applaud loudly and yell vocally when Voldemort was defeated. Our's was packed and not a peep from anyone when he was killed by Harry. There you have it. It would have brought the ending to OUTSTANDING, IMHO.

Arriva finalmente lo scontro finale, la battaglia tra bene e male si svolge nel luogo in cui quasi tutti gli eventi della serie si sono svolti, riassumendo alla perfezione tutta la saga.
Purtroppo la battaglia è troppo rapida per potersela godere a pieno, incentrata totalmente sui personaggi principali, lasciando pochissimi secondi a tutti i comprimari.
Memorabili i due minuti di riassunto concessi al personaggio di Severus Piton, commoventi e potenti come pochi.
Finale all'altezza di una saga cinematografica che segnerà la storia della cinematografia per la lungimiranza ed il coraggio con cui è stata intrapresa e portata alla conclusione.
Come onnnn this has to be the worst HP movie, or one of the two worst movies of HP.

Amazing .. Goosebumps. Best of all the harry potter movies. A great Thrill ride. Every thing was all setup in all its last installments, This movie delivers a great mixture of thrill, adventure, comedy, emotions, action.. and a great faceoff between death lord and Harry potter ... It Ends and It Ends well .. WOW
spoiler: the hallows are voldemorts children

I don't have much to say here that hasn't already been said. This movie hardly competes with any other because of its circumstances where the somewhat flawed buildup was all shoved into a different movie entirely, leaving this one with the sole task of delivering a lengthy fan-service climax to the entire franchise with a practically unlimited budget and plenty of characters whose arcs were 95% finished. The plot revelations were the best part of the movie, followed by the special effects, then the acting prowess displayed by the leads (especially Fiennes and Bonham Carter in this one), then the dramatic and memorable film score. The most touching scene of the movie and perhaps the entire series for me was Hermione offering to go into the woods with Harry - it came off incredibly altruistic and human, hitting me right in the feels unexpectedly in a way that Snape's memories did not. There were some things I would've preferred to see happen with the characters than what did, though that's mainly a very minor gripe with the source material. This was extremely successful as an ending to the series and deserves its spot as the highest-rated movie in it, even if that's mostly for getting to adapt only the exciting parts of one of the novels. Kudos!
This movie ended the Harry Potter series on a terrible note. I can't believe this shameful. And after the success of the earlier films too!

Here we are at the end of arguably the best YA series of novels adapted to film of all time. If the previous three film (Order of Phoenix, Half-Blood Prince, and Deathly Hallows part 1) if these films were the resistance underground films, this one is the out and out war film with wall to wall action, separated by a few tender quieter moments in between. In the last stand battle of Hogwarts everybody showed their bravery. Dame Maggie Smith's Prof. Mcgonagall got a moment to show how badass she is taking over Hogwarts, and Neville Longbottom was one of the most courageous young wizards, standing up for the Dark Lord himself. He was so brave he earned the right to wield the Sward of Gryffindor and truly save the day. That said, the true sacrifice came from Snape, the most misunderstood hero of the story. He gave up his entire life and managed to live as an outcast for years just to protect Harry and fool the Dark Lord, he managed to have a final moment with Harry which just made me very emotional.
The final showdown between Harry and Voldemort was short and sweet. The Dark Lord's hubris lead to his downfall after our heros managed to take him down piece by piece working together, and utilizing the Deathly Hallows for good not for personal gains. The film then was bookended with a happy scene at the train to Hogwarts 16 years later, with the new generation of wizards starting their first year at the school. It is a lovely scene that mirrors the one from the first film, and I could not think of a better ending.

Amazing conclusion to the series, the film is one big emotional journey, with great action scenes and more quiet moments, one of the highlights is the score and pacing of the story. However the final showdown between Harry Potter and Voldemort, where they chase each other around Hogwarts, was weird and unnecessary, and Neville's shining moment from the book was anticlimactic in the movie. The time wasted on Potter/Voldemort chase could have been used on more important scenes such as the death of Fred Weasley or another important character. But the movie is still fantastic and manages to be a satisfying ending
The heartwarming and heartbreaking end to an amazing story is so shocking and action packed. Stakes also add to the fact that i believe it's the greatest Harry Potter movie
A great finish to a fantastic series. Really enjoyable.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows part 2 is a great send off to an overwhelmingly amazing saga. From the satisfying character arcs to the tender and memorable moments; Deathly Hallows Part 2 puts everything together and leaves nothing out. This review will probably be the sshortest I've made regarding the Harry Potter series. Mainly because I have virtually ZERO gripes about it. There are a few things throughout the movie that are not explained well, but nothing too crazy. Pretty much just nitpicks. But yeah, great final chapter and I'm extremely satisfied. Goodnight...

What to say about this film, it is an ending that leaves us all with a happy ending and that fills us with joy to see how Harry, Hermione and Ron, manage to close their argumentative arc. I feel that in this saga, I lack a better villain than Voldemort, it was not bad, but it could be better. Very sad to have finished these films since I feel that I can continue to see many more films from this universe and that is something in which the directors were right, in attracting the public more and more. Without a doubt my two favorite characters are Harry and Hermione, they are the most complete and the talent of one complements the intelligence of another, nothing more than adding a 9/10 to the saga.

Very well acted movie. It really the best film of harry potter series if you are searching for a good film then this is it. But harry must marry hermione not ginny. At end he got all deathly hallows but he breaks elder wand still its one of the greatest movies. I LOVE MAGIC !

This movie I watched it for the first time as a kid. It is an amazing movie for me. It helps create my imagination. I love this movie so much In my view, the film is perfectly flawless, telling the story of the growth of the characters. Made me feel growing up with them

This was a very good, beautifully done ending to this story. It's basically a complex war film with wands instead of guns; it carefully tied up the loose ends, still had ground-breaking revelations to the ones who hadn't read the book before it came out and it featured the epilogue. This whole franchise is a journey and it ends in jolly tears.

While I might've not enjoyed this movie as much when it first came out in 2011, I can finally see why many people would say that THIS is the best Harry Potter movie. When first seeing this movie in the theaters, I had no idea what to think of this movie. But as a teenager, when first getting into the Harry Potter franchise, after watching all the other seven movies and before reading all seven books, I was amazed by how fantastic this movie was in comparison to all the other movies that were made over the last ten years. I would even say that this movie is even better than The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King! If you like either of these two movies, I'd still say that this is the one you must watch! My overall opinion: 10/10!
They made 8 amazing movies. Casting was near perfect.
Great way to end the series.
What a masterpiece!!
what a conclusion to the Harry Potter Universe. I love big scale battles, the duels are very well shot and it's sad to see this be the last Harry potter film. Voldemort is also an awesome villain.

Very satisfying Ending to the Harry Potter franchise! This movie - the end to the HP series - is more stunning and excting than all the other HP movies! This 8th film has lead to amazing moments, tears, and revolution! I have to give this movie more attention than all the others; it is way better than you could expect! In this ending of the HP series, it was filled with what the books had - it really followed the book well. (I am picky about how the movies follow the books!) And I have to say, this movie really followed the book more than I thought! Yes, I saw some errors in this movie but it was more amazing that I could care less about these errors! The ending to the HP series is really sad and a bit disturbing, filled with lots of epic-battle moments! You don't have to be a HP fan to love this movie!

The second part to Deathly Hallows was just as great as the first part. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, Emma Watson, Ralph Fiennes, and the rest of the cast did a fantastic job in this movie. The plot of the movie was very dramatic, thrilling, and adventurous. It explains everything about what's been going on throughout the entire movie series. If you haven't seen this last Harry Potter movie, check it out after you see the previous movies in order. It'll be worth it.
AMAZING! IT IS A MUST WATCH!

The Deathly Hallows - Part 2 is the epic and satisfying finale deserved for such a magical film series like Harry Potter. It holds more emotional weight, action, stakes, and character than the other Harry Potter movies, creating one of the best final installments in any film series.
A disgraceful and unrealistic cash-grab of an ending to the Harry Potter movie franchise. The books are WAY BETTER!
A perfect finale to a pretty good series.

A fitting conclusion to a long adventure. There were many moments during the my most recent viewing of this after watching the subsequent films, where I got goosebumps and chills. One of the things that makes this finale work so well, is the way it utilizes elements from each chapter that led up to it. It's a different viewing experience when you watch this movie after all the others. You catch details and connection that add to the overall experience. In some ways it is reminiscent of Avengers: Endgame in that, everything comes together without failing to deliver. It seems like having the chance to direct multiple films allowed David Yates to accumulate a sensibility for what worked and what didn't. This is evident in an ending that brings together the most important parts of the books, and nowhere is this more evident than in Part 2.

As a big Harry Potter fan this movie is everything you could want! They tied up a lot of great storylines and gave great fan service. It was great being with the characters you've loved over 10 years for one last adventure! Big revelations to enjoy!

Along with The Dark Knight Rises, Avengers: Endgame and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, Deathly Hallows part 2 is a showing of a perfect finale. Every loose end, every character arc is resolved in a satisfying way, all structed around what is, in esscenece a war movie. The soundtrack is particularly striking, and the multiple long-takes and callbacks are very well-executed. The Resurrection Stone in the Forest, the Princes tale, the dragon flight, there are so many thrilling and emotional moments in this dark but wildly entertaining and rewatchable climax to a franchise I hold very close to my heart | Grade: A+
A finale for the ages, even if the movie takes some liberties with the story.
Brilliant! Nothing more to say. I do however wish they would have included some scenes they decided on leaving out, but the movie can only be so long I guess.

This is how you end a movie franchise brilliantly. 
It differed from the books in most of the right places (eg battle scenes) but kept the plot line really well. Great acting by Ralph Fiennes, Daniel Radcliffe and others
This movie is just great it perfectly brings the final instalment to the saga the only flaw is it does miss some things out of the books

Directly following the events of "Deathly Hollows Part 1" Harry (Danielle Radcliffe), Hermione (Emma Watson), and Ron (Rupert Grint) continue their search for Voldemorts (Ralph Fiennes) horcruxs. 

This film is in my opinion the best in the franchise. This film is the shortest of the series which means it is very faced paced compared to the rest. The film gets going very quickly and never really slows down because it doesn't need to. At this point they have developed the characters and all of the plot lines which mean this film doesn't need to set up anything, it just needs to close. Everything was ended in an extremely satisfying way. Whether it be the emotional end of Snape (Alan Rickman), the long awaited relationship between Hermione and Ron, or the death of Voldemort this is an extremely satisfying film.

The scene that gives me goosebumps whenever I watch it is when McGonagall (Maggie Smith) activates the guards. The combination of music and cinematography makes for one of my favourite scenes in the entire franchise. 

The action in this film is extremely well handled and we get to see a lot of these characters get their moment to shine. In particular Neville's (Matthew Lewis) moment when he gives a heartwarming speech at then proceeds to kill Nagini is one of the greatest character moments in the series.

There are some confusing points in this film that I think definitely could've been polished up and there are a few to many things that happen off camera but it doesn't take to much away from the masterpiece that this film is.

9.5/10
Good movie, a true master peice

A fantastic and satisfying finale. While the film moves a lil bit too quick at points, it manages to do a great job with the many themes and moments that took place in the books, while providing epic action sequences as well! While the magic and happiness once felt in this saga are no longer present imo, the maturity and compelling narrative make up for it and it all delivers so well in this final film of the best saga ever!
I love all the Harry Potter movies. This one was an incredible conclusion to series.

La mia opinione circa questo film è che come finale della saga cinematografica dovesse essere molto di più di questo, probabilmente se fosse stato nelle mani di un regista con più abilità sarebbe potuto essere un film degno di grandissimo merito.
Cosa che invece non è stato del tutto, per me.
Molte delle tematiche profondissime trattate dal settimo libro sono state trascurate all'interno del film, come l'argomento della Morte e degli stessi Doni della Morte, che nonostante si presentino nel titolo non svolgono alcun ruolo all'interno del relativo film. Un altro problema di questi quattro film è che non riescano a far funzionare correttamente il titolo al loro interno. 
La battaglia di Hogwarts in questo film è senza dubbio emozionante, ma poteva anche non ricoprire un ruolo così vasto da dimenticare il resto.
Anche questo non lo giudico un film terribile, ma indiscutibilmente non un capolavoro.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows concludes the long running franchise in epic fashion, with a finale that satisfies on an emotional and visceral level. Tying everything together from a 8 film franchise is no small task, and I think the filmmakers have truly nailed it here. There is no shortage of character moments, bringing back classic fan favorites as well as introducing some characters that are "new" to the audience but feel like they have been a part of this universe all along. The performances are wonderful across the board, practically all of the actors we have known from Sorcerer's Stone turn in their best performance in this film. Rickman, Radcliffe, Grint, Watson, and many more bring their A-game for this finale. The visuals are at their best, with some truly epic and kinetic moments of CGI-enhanced magical action. Many threads are picked up on, well connected, with a tidy bow on top and it's filled to the brim with fan-pleasing moments. Unless you genuinely don't care for the Harry Potter series, you should be truly impressed with this conclusion.
WHAT A FINAL FOR THIS STORY!

A more than fitting swansong to a far more than ordinary saga. The Deathly Hallows: Part 2 is a stunning cinematic achievement, crafting a supremely satisfying final chapter with mesmerising wizardry, soul-shattering emotion, powerhouse performances, wicked visuals, thrilling narrative pacing and a rousing final act that closes the Harry Potter series out in nothing short of spectacular fashion.
Left here is no longer just a literary legacy --- an artistic one rather.
Iroh's grade: A-

The finale of the Harry potter franchise was amazing. The actors were at their best. The cinematography was stunning, the characters arcs came to a satisfying end, the editing+sound editing was amazing, great music. Amazing final battle, defiantly a must watch, very enjoyable!

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 is one of the most gratifying ways to end a series. After such a long series, you're hoping that the end does the rest of the series justice and thIS movie doesn't disappoint in the slightest. It's the harrowing conclusion to Harry Potter's journey as he tries to put a stop to the evil Voldemort once and for all.

Acting: 10
It's not surprise that the acting is so stellar as these wonderful actors/actresses have had years to grow comfortable in the skin of their characters. Daniel Radcliffe continues to be sensational in his role as Harry Potter as he embraces Potter's ascension into manhood. Rupert Grint (Ron) and Emma Watson (Hermione) shine yet again playing his dedicated friends and sidekicks. You can tell that the three of them have formed such a strong bond over the eight movies as their synergy is extremely on point.

Beginning: 4

Characters: 10
This final film pulls out all the stops as it's an all-out good vs. evil war. Teeming with amazing characters, I was hardpressed trying to uncover who exactly my favorite was. Potter is wonderful, yes, but so are dozens of others literally. I was really impressed with the maturation of Ron's character. It can be hard at times developing a sidekick but in some ways, Ron's journey to completion is just as satisfying as Harry's.

Cinematography/Visuals: 10

Conflict: 10
This one is for all the marbles so they hold nothing back when it comes to amazing action sequences. The battles sprawl all across Hogwarts filled with dope magic and wonder. Sparks fly in abundance of blacks, greens and reds across a dark backdrop, a spectacular display. Sometimes you have no idea who's even winning, but it looks damn cool.

Entertainment Value: 10
Potter vs. Voldemort alone is worth the price of admission. The battle definitely lives up to the hype. Even moreso to see closure happen on every level is a welcome treat. Outside of a slow(ish) start, the movie is enjoyable from beginning to end.

Memorability: 10

Pace: 10
The beauty of the final book being done in two parts for the movie is they definitely saved the best for last. All the best battles and memorable scenes are jam-packed into Part 2, causing things to fly by at a breakneck pace. Just over two hours, the final installment just flies by.

Plot: 10
JK Rowling wraps up this beautiful adventure quite nicely. The thing I keep going back to and have an immense amount of respect for: No loose ends. The stakes are higher than ever in this story that succeeds with a few cool twists along the way.

Resolution: 10

Overall: 94
The magical battles alone are enough to make Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 worth a watch. With the combination of rich characters who each get a proper sendoff, a speedy pace, and a chunk of memorable moments, this is a movie to remember.
The 8th and final movie in the magical, wonderful, AMAZING series.

I can't express how good the Harry Potter saga was, and this movie. With each film I watched, I saw the characters growing and maturing, from adventures and lessons at school to a great battle for the life of the world, then seeing the protagonists having their own families while their children go to study at Hogwarts.

An exciting and fun saga and also, a must.
Special Effects: 1,0/Sound Effects: 1,0/Acting: 1,0/Story: 2,0

Final chapter of this epic series lacks the adventure and creativity of the previous films. The early scenes featuring the dragon in the bank vault are the highlight. All out war at Hogwarts pretty much takes up the rest of the film.

It culminates with a battle fitting of the two greatest powers in the world.
In retrospect, it ends the way it should and without being all too predictable.

Based on this generation's most impressive work of science-fiction, the Harry Potter movies exceed the standard with their presentation and the finale is, as it should be, the best of the set.

The movie did not disappoint. It was as great as the others. I am so glad that they brought them back to the bid screen. It was great to be able to take my daughter to see it on the big screen since she was not alive when the film's were originally released

Way too imbalanced toward battles, thanks to the studio's decision to split this into 2 movies. This film is action action action without much else which makes it too heavy to watch more than once in a long while.

The second half of Harry's grand finale is better than the first, but still struggles to cope with too many characters, too little color and an overstuffed dance card. There's just so much going on, and it's all so excessively dim...

Over-reliance upon book lore has been a long-term problem for this franchise, and that issue has only grown more pronounced as the film adaptations enter their final stretch. I have no idea how anyone could make sense of Deathly Hallows 2 without keeping a store of such information, fresh and reliable, somewhere in their noggin. Maybe a Cliff's Notes handbook and a hair-trigger pause button would suffice. Casually tossing about complicated concepts like wand allegiance, multiplying spells, hallows and horcruxes, the film skims along at a high speed, in breathless pursuit of flashier material. Of that, fortunately, there's plenty, and those bits are loaded with well-constructed callbacks to the previous films. The action scenes are constant highlights, excellent in concept and in execution; a fitting farewell, in their own way, for the series at large.

Quieter character moments are more of a mixed bag. Snape gets his big spotlight scene, after being completely ignored in the previous chapter, but most of the younger cast members are swept up in the desperate search for a soul mate. Everybody just wants to pair off, to hit that convenient epilogue with a litter of kids tugging at their shoestrings. Despite simmering for years and years, in many cases, such romances play more like a series of checked boxes than natural, heartfelt outpourings of emotion. Ron and Hermione are a prime example. The moment of their long-germinating embrace was evidently a difficult scene for the actors, who literally grew up together on-set, and their discomfort is clear on the screen. The kiss feels like an awkward, instantly-regretted smooch between friends, not a grand culmination, and that robs power from these beloved characters' storybook ending. They probably should've got that out of the way several movies earlier anyway. Here, in the midst of a hectic chase and a frenzied battle, even an effective payoff would've been lost in the mix.

Which is another recurring issue that this film never really settles. There's enough material for three movies in here (or a seven-hundred page book, as it were) and in trying to please everyone, to fit it all in, the whole package fades into a fleeting, dizzying wash. Nothing gets a chance to breathe, lest a different scene meet the cutting room floor. Crucial time is cut from meaningful points in the main narrative, dampening their impact, to cram in a few smaller, crowd-pleasing tidbits. But those, too, are over and done with so quickly that they hardly seem worth the effort.

In the end, we get (nearly) everything, without necessitating another weird mid-stream cutaway, but nothing is half as rewarding as I'd expected. A stumble over the finish line, in other words; a film that hits the novel's plot points but completely misses its spirit. Could've been worse, I guess, but it also could've been so much better.
AMAZING BECAUSE IT ALL ENDS.

I am a huge fan of the Harry Potter books, they're all so great and magical. But I didn't think the film series were perfect at all, but they were still great movies. With that, I was extremely excited to see the end of the film franchise, and impressed with the trailers. So I had high expectations. And thankfully it did not disappoint, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part II, blew past my already high expectations and I was enthralled!

The whole movie looked spectacular! The cinematography extremely well done, the art direction was incredible. The movie was beautiful to look at, the visuals were spectacular and truly Oscar worthy! The set designers, cinematographers really need to be awarded for their work, because it looks like they spend of time and money on the look of the film.

The cast of the film was pretty much perfect, they should all be applauded too. Emma Watson, as usual is and great and she'll have a bright career ahead of her. Rupert Grint is pretty much great also, he is a fine actor indeed. Daniel Radcliffe did an amazing job and was very memorable as Harry Potter. Although I think Ralph Fiennes was the star of the film, he did unbelievable job as the evil, crazy Lord Voldemort, I think he deserves an Oscar Nomination for his role. The rest of the cast were also great too.

We all grew up overtime with the series, we followed the adventures of Harry Potter for around 10 years, I think. It seems very weird that there will be no more Harry Potter films to look forward too. I will miss the franchise very much! However I am happy the series got an amazing ending. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part II is not only the best film in the series, but it will probably be one of the best films of 2011. Everyone should see this film, even if they don't like past Harry Potter films.

The movie was what I was hoping it would be which was full action and amazing visuals. The story is great and it's a great way to end the franchise. This film is probably my favorite out of all the movies.

Probably the most gratifying and faithful conclusion to any franchise and all-time since The Return of the King. It was an amazingly coherent, fast rollacoaster (almost too quick at times), all the way to the very end. Yet, it wrapped everything up so effortlessly and effectively to near flawlessness. The ending final scene was warm, touching and was absolutely perfect.

This movie was incredible, the production and set design, the scoring, and especially the visual effect was packed verry well and it made a wonderful movie. Overall the movie was an nobel end for Harry Potter saga, so great job 👍👍
Best Harry Potter movie. I know it's hard for some to admit but it's just a perfect ending get over your personal opinions

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2, is well acted, perfectly shot, sometimes funny, and ends the series on a good note. The Battle of Hogwarts is amazing to see on screen, and Snape's memory scene is heartbreaking. Combined with a nice choir like score this Final chapter is almost perfect. The only nitpick is that the movie is very fast paced, making it go by very fast, and some parts do feel a bit rushed. This is my favorite Harry Potter film in the series. So 9.5/10, the ultimate Harry Potter movie.

The epic finale 10 years in the making. This film is a quick rollercoaster start to finish. This film sees all of our stories come to an end in emotional and satisfying ways. Even to this point there are still twists yet to be uncovered and our actors spare no expense on their emotional performances. My biggest complaint with Part 2 is that the battles felt like cgi montages versus battles being described in the novel. The film is epic and emotional but just didn’t have all the punches I really wanted out of it. Even with that minor complaint, this is a solid ending to a beloved franchise.

It's a satisfactory ending to the series for me. It's a fast paced movie (even though the beginning is boring to me for some reason) which is a nice refresher after seeing the first part of the movie. The Snape scene is beautiful. Less Neville would've been nice, but I guess geeks like him so he had his use. Overall, a decent Harry Potter movie.

so i am talking about the end of the movie when harry kills voldemort, don't get me wrong this scence was great! and when i saw it for the last time i enjoyed! but after i thought about it, i am kind of disppointed  that the end was not like in the book... 
in the book harry talk to voldemort while everyone was listening, and it was so exciting!!! and even if it less big and shiny i still think it could have been much more exciting with the book's end! but as i say in the start if you did not watch the movie go watch it! and if you never saw harry potter movies or read the books...what is wrong with you?!

A faithful conclusion to a fun series. With all its other details of production hammered out, and a simple excursion into the end of the film, it was very possible for Deathly Hallows Pt. 2 to drop the ball at the last second by either straying from the source material or otherwise getting distracted by some other creative attribution. Fortunately, this doesn't happen, and the film is allowed its final moments of grief, danger, combat in peace. The scenes are fantastically executed, faithful to the source, exciting to behold (you get them Mrs. Weasley!), and places the carpet for a long-time, newly crowned classic of fantasy film to step away from its grand pedestal and retire in a place of peace.

Wow, that's what you will say when you watch this concluding film in the Harry Potter series, it's just amazing how consistently great this series is especially considering that it has eight movies and the last one is truly the best of them all. David Yates closed this series with a deeply moving conclusion to these film adaptations and I am amazed how well this two-part finale worked out, you can totally see how this last book warranted being split in two and it was honestly for the best. I am very pleased with how they wrapped up all of the plotlines and made them feel like a satisfying conclusion that we've been building up to for the past 10 years, the journey that these characters all went on was well worth the reward considering how many hours we put into supporting their development and it absolutely works for me, this was a great heart-wrenching finale with some really good action sprinkled throughout, it is pretty fast-paced and it never fails to entertain on every level including emotionally. The flashback with Snape and Lilly was so heartbreaking and well done, I felt for Snape so much and loved him even more as a character and Alan Rickman played him to perfection, scenes like that test how emotionally invested we got in the characters and for me, my heartstrings tugged every single time. This movie makes the weaker movies Half-Blood Prince and the Columbus films totally worth watching, not that they were bad, but they didn't stand on their own as movies nearly as well as the other ones, this pays off all of the time you invested in this series and it feels cohesive and complete. Another amazing thing in this film is that the stakes have never been higher and they feel so real, it feels like there will be consequences and it makes this even more intense, with the deaths of Lupin, Tonks, and Fred, it made everyone feel vulnerable and human in a world filled with magic, it got us to worry about everyone we know and made us feel justice when Harry achieves victory. I greatly appreciated that David Yates didn't milk this last movie by making it long and drawn out for no reason, it does its job quickly, it takes more time with the character development when it needs to, it isn't boring and it feels complete and satisfying, I only wish that there was more time given to Malfoy and actually having him going through with siding with Harry, his character arc feels incomplete and just hanging there with no resolution. This is the shortest film in the series and it works very well as a conclusion, it feels earned, the stakes are real, it consistently entertains and I get emotional every time. This is my favorite film in the series and it caps off this franchise very nicely.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 is absolutely breathtaking! David Yates has been a favorable director for these films, and he really showcased his talents here. He crafted so many gorgeous shots, with a couple new creative tricks, while Mark Day's editing was absolutely seamless, really knitting the scenes together beautifully.

David Yates let Part 1 take all the set up hits, and completely focused on making this a high octane, blast of fun! Yates does an amazing job of bringing all of the former events and foreshadowing together, to create countless amazing moments! There were so many twists and turns, keeping the narrative fresh, while moving at such a brisk pace with great momentum. Yates does a fantastic job of setting up this really dark and dreary tone, backed up by the amazing cinematography, and a great score, while really balancing the emotional keys well with the dark tone.

It has been a great honor and pleasure to have seen all of these characters grow and mature, over the seventeen years of the saga - it's truly sad to say that it's over. Yates does an amazing job of bringing in all of the characters from the past films, and balancing them super well within the narrative. There were just countless great character moments, displaying their true talents in their own way. After all this time, you can really feel and understand the characters motives and feelings, because everyone is fleshed out so nicely, having great chemisty across the board.

As a finale should be, the magic and action sequences were off the charts! It was by far the best showing of their magical abilities, having so many intriguing sequences! The amount of stakes that were set was amazing, having constant tention throughout the entire narrative.

Overall, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2, is phenomenal! It is by far the most entertaining film of the saga, and arguably the best; I just can't put it over The Prisoner of Azkaban!
A worthy final that does right what part one did wrong. The action is fantastic and the story emotional. Sure to please fans of all ages.
The finale of the Harry Potter series was executed beautifully, especially in completing Snape's character arc. It will remain a token for a generation and beyond. After all this time? Always.

Non esattamente il gran finale che mi sarei aspettato dopo la qualità di tutto il franchise in generale. La conclusione di questa colossale saga cinematografica è assolutamente positiva per ogni tipologia di pubblico, ma cade in errori estremamente banali che dovevano essere obbligatoriamente evitati. In primis, non c'è sufficiente spazio narrativo per le morti dei vari personaggi, che cadono senza motivazione senza che gli venga data meritata giustizia. Inoltre, nella seconda parte della pellicola lo scontro finale risulta parzialmente frettoloso e non convincente al cento per cento. Stupende invece alcune piccole scelte registiche e narrative che inglobano tutto il percorso dei personaggi iniziato con il primissimo film. Nel complesso si tratta di un finale leggermente sottotono rispetto alle previsioni, ma che riesce comunque ad offrire emozioni forti e sincere a tutti i numerosi appassionati.

When I think of a stellar movie, I immediately think of this box office smash hit. 

The story is a continuation of the story of the famous Harry Potter. It starts with the bubbling wizarding war that is about to topple over in instant destruction. You can feel the tension in the air with the character's breathing and body language. The way that the story unfolds is like nothing ever seen. In my mind, it doesn't follow the status quo of Disney or Paramount (love stories, buddy stories, road trips and such).

The characters are stellar. They play their parts phenomenally. The casting of Ian Hart, Helena Bonham Carter, and of course, Daniel Radcliffe was an amazing choice. The performances really dazzle audiences to this day. You can feel the warmth of the greeting when Harry comes to Hogwarts for the final battle. It gives off the impression that there really is such a thing as Hogwarts.

The setting feels so real and authentic that you sometimes wonder if it all was CGI and a blue screen. They characters interact in such a way that it makes you feel that they're all really best friends and not people from random parts of Europe. The chemistry between the characters is sensational.

Overall an amazing movie and I wouldn't miss it for the world!!!!!!!!

David Yates directed a wonderful finale for his adaptation of J. K. Rowling's iconic children's series: Harry Potter. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part II (2011) is not only far superior to the dull Part I, but a tight picture that ties up all the loose ends, answering questions audiences have held onto for a decade, giving satisfying conclusions for all its characters. Yates directs The Deathly Hallows Part II with a focused perspective, swift pace, and attention to detail for explaining various mysteries left unanswered by previous films in the series. 

J. K. Rowling's writing is precise and interesting as she connects the dots between Snape's deeds by shifting his crimes into sacrifices in a devastating final performance from Alan Rickman. Yates' direction makes Snape's backstory appear ambiguous like Snape could have even been Harry's father despite book implications. Rowling revealing that Snape had been protecting Harry due to his love of Harry's mother Lily Potter is endearing, devastating, and shocking all at once. Finding out Harry was a horcrux too, who needs to die is sad, but gets resolved in a neat way. I don't particularly care for the train station waypoint to Heaven as it's a very on the nose metaphor beneath the series, but it gets the point across I suppose.

Alexandre Desplat's score is epic and sweeping with grandeur worthy of Harry Potter's finale. It's too bad it's not as magical and memorable as John Williams' original score, but Desplat brings fiery composition to his music. I'm quite happy Harry and Ginny end up together, while I guess it was fate for Hermione and Ron as their relationship was developed from the beginning. Daniel Radcliffe, Bonnie Wright, Emma Watson, and Rupert Grint all bring their best for this emotional final film in the Harry Potter series.

Ralph Fiennes is fearsome and scary with his Shakespearean take on Lord Voldemort. Jason Isaac is great as the cowardly Lucius Malfoy, meanwhile Helen McCrory and Tom Felton are excellent as the redeemed villains Narcissa and Draco Malfoy. Helena Bonham Carter is excellent fun in a more playful role for Bellatrix in all her insane antics.

Overall, it's a fun last movie that is emotionally poignant and enthralling narratively.
It's so good. It is so good. The way it ties back to the other films, the emotion it has, and the epic ending to it all... I love this movie. I love this series. I think everyone should too.

While the expectations were certainly sky-high for the final entry to a film series that defined a generation, Deathly Hallows Part 2 serves as a satisfactory, if not particularly radical, conclusion. Seeing actors mature and adapt to their roles over more than a decade ultimately imparts more of an impact than the narrative itself, though new viewers may be forced to assess the merits of the series more objectively. But seriously: bad acting, bad writing, so many action/fight/chase scenes that you'd swear it's an American movie (hey...) and a plot so convoluted and opaque that every 10 minutes my wife had to explain something to me.  
Ok, I know: I'm not a Potter Cognoscenti (Cognoscentum?) but damn it, you shouldn't HAVE to be to enjoy a movie.  You shouldn't have to be an expert in the Potter Canon (yes, I know many 12 year olds would qualify).  The one thing that was good, but now is good in virtually all movies, was the CGI (no, wait: Air Strike with Bruce Willis looked like something put together by Hanna Barbera).  Full marks to the poor slaves banging away at their 1000 computer terminals to turn this stuff out.  They're pretty damned good at it.

Deathly Hallows part 2 ends this incredibly well produced saga with tremendous grace and a beautifully orchestrated climax that I am sure will satisfy both lovers of the books and films.

If you have read the books as I have you will be glad to know major key moments are intact. Much is missing but I won't dwell on that, no point, its how well this movie plays out and for me it rolls wonderfully between excitement, thrills and emotional drama towards a satisfactory (though a slightly rushed) conclusion. 

There are at least 2 sequences so powerful that I defy anyone not to at least stifle a tear or choke a little. One of those sequence is an exquisitely executed flashback that is pivotal to the whole story. 

I have to say, that despite the woes we book readers have when elements (big chunks of it too) are omitted from the movies, much credit still has to go to Steve Kloves for adapting the books for the big screen, cleverly weaving, changing and even adding new big elements to give a kinetic flow to the narrative and here it all comes together superbly.

David Yates assured direction has nurtured our young actors in the last 4 films to blossom into even more adept actors who convey their characters with natural tones without overacting. Daniel Radcliffe had to carry this movie more than any other and has done so brilliantly complemented with great support from his two companions, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint.

Pretty much all the characters we have met in all the movies have made an appearance in this finale but one actor stands out, Alan Rickman. His portrayal of Professor Snape has always been a joy to watch (if a little novel) but here his scenes will leave a dramatic engraving in my memory. Here he elevates his portrayal of one of the most complex character in young adult literature to an unforgettable piercingly emotional one.

Another actor who really shines in the few scenes that he has, is Matthew Lewis as Neville Longbottom who we see gradually transforming over the past films from the clumsy bullied boy to a brave warrior in this final film. Many other British thespians of the series also have their few moments to shine especially Maggie Smith's Professor McGonagal who was a delight to watch as she takes charge of the defence of Hogwarth School.

As for the spectacle of the battle and showdowns, while not at the scale of Lord of the Rings, I honestly cant think how it could have been done better as the film makers have intertwined heart stopping action with dramatic progressions in the narrative. Its actually more visceral and dynamic than the rather smaller scale battle of the brilliant novels (not to take anything away from Rowling's writing). 

Do I have any gripes? Yes I do. Although I applaud Steve Kloves for a difficult screenplay adaption...I think he could still have done better at explaining some odd anomalies that only readers of the book will understand. This might annoy you if you haven't read the books. But its a small gripe because what we get is delightful.

What an amazing achievement to faithfully bring Rowling's epic saga to the big screen with the same cast and largely the same crew, maintaining the brilliant quality right to the end.

Oh my god, its only just sinking in, this was the end....but what a great great end.An incredible journey that began a decade ago finally arrives at its close with David Yates' "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part II", as 'The Boy Who Lived' comes face to face with 'He Who Shall Not Be Named' in an epic showdown between good and evil. And what a showdown it is- tense, thrilling, breathtaking, and fitting of just about any superlative you can think of. 

Whereas the first instalment of the 'Deathly Hallows' emphasised the profound sense of loss and isolation among Harry, Ron and Hermoine, screenwriter Steve Kloves and director Yates leaves behind the moody atmosphere of the previous movie for newfound immediacy and urgency. This is all about that final battle where only one can live, and from start to finish- for once in a Harry Potter movie- the action is swift and relentless.

Part II picks up right where the previous film left off- the dark Lord Voldemort smiles in evil triumph as he steals the most powerful wand in the world, i.e. the Elder Wand, from the tomb of beloved Hogwarts headmaster Professor Dumbledore (Michael Gambon). The next shot is equally ominous- students are marched rank-and-file through a Hogwarts courtyard, watched closely by cloaked Dementors hovering over the school grounds. If there was any need of a reminder of the danger facing our three protagonists, these opening sequences should just about refresh one's memory of what is at stake.

There is precious little time to waste, and the first we get to see Harry, Ron and Hermione, they are already hatching a plan to break into Gringotts to retrieve a Horcrux. Their break-in settles upon a plan of deception that allows for some rare moments of levity in the film, as Helena Bonham Carter gets to ham it up as a polyjuice-disguised Hermoine impersonating Bellatrix Lestrange. This being the first 'Harry Potter' movie in 3D, Yates caters for some distinctive thrills in the additional dimension with a roller-coaster ride through the vault, culminating in a daring escape on the back of a dragon.

But as readers of the book will tell you, the last stand happens back at Hogwarts, and true enough, after this thrilling early set-piece at Gringotts, the trio head back to the School of Witchcraft and Wizardry to confront their foes. It is also where the last Horcruxes are supposed to be, and Harry's return to the once sunny and cheery grounds now besieged by darkness and doom becomes a true test of allegiance. 

Fans will be glad that Kloves gives room for otherwise supporting characters to step into the limelight- in particular, Neville Longbottom (Matthew Lewis) emerges as one of the unlikeliest but also truest heroes on the side of good. The Hogwarts stalwarts also get a chance to show off their magic, and Yates gives each largely enough screen time for the heroic send-off they deserve.

Yet he reserves the most emotional moment in the film for Severus Snape's (Alan Rickman) vindication, long thought to be the Judas Iscariot-equivalent in the Order and the one who pushed Dumbledore to his death. Yates delivers a truly poignant and deeply heartfelt revelation of Snape's true colours, and it is a farewell that even those who have read the book and can expect what is to come will be overwhelmed by its sheer emotional muscle. While Part II was always meant to be an action-packed spectacle, it is to Yates' credit that there is still as much heart as before in the storytelling.

Though brief, this revelation also works brilliantly as a catalyst that propels Harry to come to terms with the sacrifice he has to make. Harry's realization of this leads up perfectly to the ultimate duel between him and Voldemort, one that is fierce, ferocious and- thanks to Yates' imagination- more exhilarating than reading it off the page. 

The outcome of that battle shouldn't be a secret by now, and when the 'happily-ever-after' coda in Rowling's book set 19 years later is also faithfully adapted here, you can't quite help but be moved by how it so properly gives the series closure.

They are of course no longer kids here- Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson now young adults who have through the film series grown up right under our eyes. While Part I had greater emphasis on Ron and Hermoine, the focus here is squarely on Harry and Radcliffe truly shines in this instalment- his usual understated performance allowing his audience to appreciate the enormities of the challenge before Harry.

That we can be so fully immersed in Harry's world is testament to the craft of each and every one of the technical team. Production designer Stuart Craig does a masterful job portraying the devastation around Hogwarts, complimented nicely by Eduardo Serra's beautiful cinematography and Mark Day's skillful editing. Alexandre Desplat's evocative score, which combines his own elegiac work with both the John Williams theme as well as Nicholas Hooper's mournful composition for the sixth movie, works magic with the visuals. And most deserving of credit is none other than director Yates himself, who has matured movie after movie to deliver a crowning achievement for the series.

Pardon us if we have also taken this opportunity to extol the merits of the 'Harry Potter' franchise- it's really hard not to considering how this is the last time we will see the Potter-world in its current incarnation. It is this to which the movie is a farewell to, and it is as beautiful a farewell as it can be, packed with visual spectacle on a scale never before seen in any of the other films and fused with the same powerful emotion as Part I and the Yates films before. All good- even great- things have to come to an end, so there is really no better way to bid adieu than with this grand and glorious final chapter.I quite luckily got the chance to see this at an early screening on July 7th.

First impressions of the film? Brilliant.

Director David Yates, who also directed the 5th, 6th and 7th films is back to direct the final. This pleases me because these 3 films are my personal favourites out of the 7 that have come out so far so I think it's fair to say that I was expecting big things from this. I'm very pleased to say that he's pulled it off ending the series in a fast paced, well written final act.

The film (in case you're wondering) picks up straight after where Part 1 ended, Voldemort (Ralph Finnes) has the most powerful wand in his possession and he's finally ready to succeed in what he tried to do over 15 years ago. He finally has the power to kill Harry Potter. I won't go into much more detail in what happens as most people will have read the book and I don't want to drop spoilers! Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson) need to seek out and destroy Voldemort's remaining Horcruxes. This is the only way that will give them a chance of stopping He Who Must Not Be Named.

Their final journey takes them to places we may not have seen recently or remembered, places such as Gringotts Bank in Diagon Alley and Hogsmeade. Along the way they encounter a variety of creatures, both friend and foe from dragons to spiders, death eaters to old friends and of course, the Dark Lord himself. Will Voldemort Succeed? Or will good trump evil? For those who haven't read the book this is your chance to find out.

What I especially love about this film and Part 1 is the direction in which they've taken, adding more cheesy lines and (for example in Part 1) that dance sequence. I feel that these small touches bring the films closer to our hearts and help us to connect with the film a lot more. Sure they leave out a lot of information that the books provide but that's the same with all film adaptations! They've got the main story down and where they've deviated from the book it has been for the best. Not everything written down on paper will translate into visually appealing footage.

Part 1 to me also felt unfinished (well it was only half the book I suppose!), I mean in the way that it was long and never seemed to climax. Sure at the end of Part 1 Voldemort gets the want he so badly seeks for and leaves then the films ends on a giant cliffhanger. Part 2 definitely adds the rest of that epicness that so many other films have towards the end. It's full of action! I definitely believe that both Part 1 and 2 are best viewed with a short as possible gap in between them. Otherwise it's like watching the first disc from one of the extended editions of The Lord of the Rings and not watching the second disc for another 6 months!

This paragraph is about the visuals and 3D. Skip to the final paragraph for final thoughts.

Visually the film is stunning from an effects point of view. From the trailer alone you can see that this film has quite a lot of action in it, crumbling buildings, hundreds of spells and lots of fire. Everything looks great, from the wand duals to the dragons it all is fantastic. Also this time around it is being showed in 3D and is the first (and (probably) last!) potter film to be shown in this way. Now I was very sceptical about this, especially since they announced that the films (originally both parts) would be converted from 2D to 3D instead of being natively filmed in 3D. I believe that what they should have done was what they did with Part 1, scrap the 3D. I'm going to say that it's not great, at times it's pretty good, but never great. For the most part it's okay. I'm going to compare it with the last blockbuster film to come out in 3D, Transformers: Dark of the Moon. The 3D effect is not even close to looking as good as what that film (shot in 3D) had. So I'm going to tell you now, 2D is the best dimension to watch this film in. Having said that if you still want to (or have to) see it in 3D by all means do, the 3D doesn't take away anything from the film, but it doesn't add much.

I will end by saying that I definitely recommend this film for everyone, especially Potter fans. The ending that many thought could easily be done wrongly has been done right. Then when you think of Part 1 and 2 as the same film I believe that they are easily the best Potter films. This truly is a fitting ending for the boy who lived.

A most fitting ending to this 10 year long movie franchise.

We follow Harry, Hermione and Ron as they continue their quest for the last Horcruxes, which takes them right to where it all started, where the battle of Hogwarts takes place. And what a battle. At times this feels like a straight war movie, be it from the battle scenes of pure chaos and blood pumping spells flying all over the place, or the tension building up from the moment the preparations start. The focus is sharp and perfectly shifts from Harry's task to the bigger picture battle going on.
The performances, commanded most of the time by the trio we've grown to love and admire, are notable from Ralph Fiennes and most of all Alan Rickman, who has been building towards this amazing emotional climax, finishing one of the most powerful arcs in the whole series.
In the end the stakes are met as we lose some characters and Yates comes to a victorious ending to the saga, finishing as strong as we could have hoped for.
Gave us a satisfying conclusion.

Very epic and a great narrative that steals bits from the bible. Rowling knows how to concoct a complex story that unwraps beautifully. Some things strike me as over the top, children story though. For one, why Voldemort would be so much an personal enemy of Potter and totally evil at the same time? That seems so mad and megalomaniac that few wizards would support him. Then, the fighting is so extensive and murderous, it seems too much, bordering on WWII. It seems that the forces at play are difficult to equalize. With so much power on each side, the outcome cannot possibly even out because it's practically impossible to stop either side from causing major casualties. 
Rowling nevertheless is thinking very intelligently. Her stories are always satisfying an complex. 
I found the epilogue very charming. Excessively charming, with all our heroes having a mini-me or two sent to the school of wizards. And the significance of the frog? Is it another reference to french, which are all over the place throughout? A french from Québec this time?

In the epic finale, the battle between the good and evil forces of the wizarding world escalates into an all-out war. The stakes have never been higher and no one is safe. But it is Harry Potter who may be called upon to make the ultimate sacrifice as he draws closer to the climactic showdown with Lord Voldemort. It all ends here. 

Everything comes to a close here. A decades worth of Harry Potter films and eight actual movies later, we get a close to our beloved franchise. In all honesty, I loved this film. I think there's so much to love about it, as it's really a sight to behold. This is how you effectively tie up years worth of stories, characters, and memories. 

One thing that this film has going for it is its soundtrack. Its score is flat out amazing and it adds so much to the film itself. After the film I went to Apple Music and downloaded my favorite songs from it. Yes, I put them on in my car and I felt epic while doing so. I guess what my point is, the music was well composed, it fit perfectly with the tone of the film, and it was memorable. 

You see all the characters you've come to know and love fight in this final chapter. Because it's the final chapter, everyone's up for fair game (in terms of major events happening to them). It makes everything just that much more tense and it makes it more emotional. It's honestly hard to watch all these beloved characters fight out a situation so dark and brutal. It makes this film really emotional, as it toyed with my heart and did it well. 

The visual effects and CGI were also phenomenal. This, along with its counterpart (Part 1) were both shot with gorgeous cinematography. If anything, this film looked as good, if not better than Part 1. The visual effects looked amazing, and it honestly looked better than some films today. There were some beautiful and mesmerizing shots, some that will become iconic in my eyes. 

In the end, this film had heart, emotion, darkness, a bit of comic relief, and an all out war. It's the war you've been waiting for, as I certainly have been waiting. It's a perfect conclusion and better yet, a fantastic series of films.
