I suppose all of you Stalkers who claim to "love my reviews" and yet never comment on them have been waiting for this one.  Or simply have seen it already out of obligation.  But here goes.

Simply put, this is a fine, FINE capstone to an iconic series and bona fide cultural phenomenon.  I have complaints--such as the amount of comic relief and the lightening of the story, as it should be deeply, deeply dark and momentous--but those are outweighed by everything that this film does RIGHT.  Some moments that were tacky in the novel are STILL tacky in the film--"Not my daughter, you bitch!"--I'm talking to you.  And some of the moments that were sweet seem tacky in the film--Ron and Hermoine's first kiss--I'm talking to you.  And, truth be told, I have a serious issue with the physicality introduced into the final Harry/Tom (NERD ALERT!) fight; did Voldemort REALLY bitch-slap Harry? But overall, I was happily whisked away by the magic of the imagery here.  How many other films can make a man like me get teary-eyed at the destruction of a SET?  Not many.  It just goes to show how attached I've become to this series, these young actors and this world.

Needless to say, the adult Brits STEAL EVERY SCENE they are in, and for every jackass that thinks this film series is about Emma and Daniel and Rupert, there are a hundred film people who know NONE of it would have worked if it wasn't for the top-notch talent around them.  Those kids may be talented youths by now, but they have had the likes of Smith, Harris, Gambon, Rickman, Thompson, Oldman, Hurt, Coltrane, Broadbent et al to thank for it.

Be that as it may, thank you, Harry Potter, for 10 years of magic.  I'll miss you.

After seven films and ten years since we walked through Diagonal Alley and Platform 9  3/4 the conclusion of Potter's story is here. After all the events we have witnessed, is this a worthy conclusion for such a beast of a franchise? 

With 3 Horcruxes taken care of and Voldemort gaining the Elder Wand, Potter and company are ready to finally confront the Dark Lord and his army of Death Eaters. Retreating to Hogwarts to find more information about the rest of the Horcruxes, Harry's friend rally around him in order to finally take down He Who Must Not Be Mentioned. 

After taking care of the exposition in "Deathly Hollows Part 1", what lies ahead is the Battle of Hogwarts and the final confrontation between The Boy Who Lived and The Dark Lord, and I have to say this final chapter is a mixed bag for me. With the focus being on the final battle between good and evil, the film does not disappoint in the action department, as it uses the franchise's strengths wisely and continues to bring new magical ideas; and it has the best dramatic sequence in the entire saga (Alan Rickman proved that he was a fantastic actor that could do so much with a stoic character) as it is satisfying and touching. But my main problem realize on the whole concept of the film: It is so focused on the battle scenes that the Horcruxes get lost in the narrative. Since "Half Blood Prince" they have been saying that the Horcruxes could be anywhere and they would be heavy protected but in reality they are not. 

"Harry Potter and the Deathly Hollows Part 2" is a bombastic conclusion to the series but it is also an underwhelming one. It is action packed, dramatic, solidly executed and extremely enjoyable.
perfect ending to an amazing 8 movies.

There is a tiny moment deep into Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2  that passes quickly but stands for a lot.  Harry Potter, now grown to manhood and sporting stubble, is visited by the ghostly apparition of his avuncular former mentor Albus Dumbledore (Michael Gambon) who looks at his pupil with caring eyes and addresses him: "Harry, you wonderful boy . . . you brave, brave  man."   Man  is the key word.  In ten years, ever since we first met Harry in Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, we saw a wonderful, fresh-faced little boy become a man of wisdom, of strength, of caution, of maturity and of leadership.  This is a character we've grown up with over ten years and now we are watching him go on to his destiny and onward to an uncertain future.

What is most refreshing about this closing chapter is that, after seven previous adventures, it is refreshing to have a hero whose mind, heart and soul are conditioned by the lessons he has learned, and not by the body count at this feet.  Death is a major factor in this concluding episode of the worldwide hit, there are many deaths, but the question looming over this chapter is whether Harry will become one of them.  There isn't a conclusive answer to that question because the ending that Rowling came up with (assuming you haven't read the book) is both baffling and fascinating at the same time.  That, in essence, has been the continuing factor of this series all along and part of the reason that we have kept coming back.  Rowling gift is that she has such a surprising sense of imagination that we don't know what she will come up with next.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2  picks up immediately where it's predecessor left off, with Harry (Daniel Radcliff) and pals Hermione Granger (Emma Watson) and Ron Weasley (Rupert Grint) seeking objects known as Horcruxes, ordinary objects that contains torn off pieces of the soul of the evil snake-faced Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes).  By this point (forgive me if my count is off) there are four that remain and Harry discovers that one of them is locked away somewhere at Hogwarts school, which was absent in the last film but occupies 90% of this one.  As Harry returns, students and teachers at Hogwarts batten down the hatches for a massive battle with Voldemort and his minions.

What is special about Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2  is that it is more than just a door-closer, more than just a vessel to tie up loose ends.  There is a lot at stake here, not the least of which is the fact that Harry must take the final steps of his journey alone.  What is interesting here is that, whereas the previous installment pushed aside most of the supporting cast, this one brings them all onstage for the final showdown - everyone gets their little moment.  Yet, the story still remains focused squarely on Harry.  This is his big moment and we see that that overly protected little tyke of 10 years ago is now a man battling the most evil being in the land single-handedly.  That battle would be nothing without a performance we can believe in and Daniel Radcliff, who has seemed distant from the material in some of the previous movies (at his worst he seemed to simply be going through the motions), finds an intense foothold on the character that lends it gravity and weight.

The movie doesn't have the overriding sense of dread that Part 1  did (that film was much better), it replaces quiet atmosphere with breathless action scenes.  In fact, after Harry returns to Hogwarts, the movie is one action scene after another.  That's both a blessing and a curse.  There are action scenes here are hit home with striking originality, such as an early scene in which Harry and friends must break into the goblin-run Gringott's Bank to steal an object from the vault of witchy-woman Bellatrix Lestrange (Helena Bonham-Carter).  I like the action scenes in these movies because they always have a spark of originality, but if there is a weakness in this last chapter, it is the feeling that the movie is rushing things.  We get to the final moments with Voldemort rather quickly, a little too  quickly I think.  This is the shortest film in the series and there is a lot of information to be imparted to the audience including the legacy of Harry's parents, the truth about Professor Snape, the mysterious machinations behind the death of Dumbledore and the steps that Harry must take to fulfill his destiny.  It is a lot to take in and I think the pacing of the previous installment was better at allowing us to get involved rather then join the film on visceral level.

What the movie does  have is a lot of great technical expertise.  The new additions to the score by Alexandre Desplat add a funerary tone to the proceedings.  They don't just tone with ominous dread but creep under certain scenes and give them gravity and weight and emotion, most especially in the scenes where the full story of Professor Severus Snape finally surfaces.  The set designs by Stuart Craig are mostly made up of rubble and debris, but as Hogwarts crumbles around hero and villain, we are reminded that Hogwarts is one of those great movies spaces that occupies our collective memories as vividly as The Death Star or Tara, Gotham City or The Bates Motel or The Emerald City.  It isn't just a set, it is a place that comfortably occupies our imaginations.  We care  about the things that go on there.

Harry Potter is a series that - both on screen and on the page - was never content to remain as it was in the beginning.  Like Harry, this is a series that has grown and matured.  Deathly Hallows Part 2  is violent but not bloody and scary but not traumatizing.  It is a polar contrast to the innocence of Sorcerer's Stone with its talking portraits and Quidditch matches (just to hammer that point home, the Quidditch field itself meets a fiery end).

It was a wise decision to split this concluding chapter into two parts.  The first part made good use of ominous silences and the spaces between the action where we could get inside Harry's feelings of dread.  This second part is just the opposite, there are few moments of quiet introspection (save for that moment with Dumbledore) and, in fact, this is one long action scene.  Is it the perfect sendoff?  It isn't as spectacular as it could have been, but I must say that I was surprised at how much this movie was able to cover in two hours and ten minutes.  When we get to the concluding scenes, it feels like a fitting farewell.  The door closes on one of the most original and creative enterprises that any author has ever put to paper.  There's a feeling of saying goodbye but an even greater feeling of what is to come.

A very solid film, but a little more originality and less fan pandering may have made it even better.

A fantastic conclusion to an epic series, Hallows Part 2 shows that it not only was worth the wait for two parts, but that if there is any measuring bar for fantasy novel adaptations, it's good old HP. If Part 1 was tense buildup, Part 2 is one of the most satisfying cinematic climaxes filmgoers are likely to see for a long time. Movie 7 Part 2 delivers in a way that Part 1 didn't even come close to doing.  Having an actual conclusion seems to help.  The final film of the series also provides bold new visuals that have not been seen in any of the other entries.  Most of the film's appeal comes from the battle for Hogwarts, which is long, drawn out, and thrilling.  The climax is mercifully altered from the somewhat dry final showdown featured in the book, setting it apart from its literary counterpart.  The fact that it's merely half the story, as well as its departure from the conventional HP formula make it slightly inferior to the third film, yet it still serves as an epically satisfying conclusion to the series.

The ending to the Harry Potter movies is certainly good, but it was not the best of the movies by any means. Perhaps I set my expectations too high after the first part, but I do feel like a lot more could've been done with this conclusion. At only two hours, surely there would've been more time to add a more suspenseful final battle and explain unexplained plot points, such as Dumbledore's past. But these are foibles compared to the glaring flaws of the previous movies. The emotions are real and the stakes are high, and I would be lying if I said I didn't cry at least twice. The acting is great, and it really feels like almost everyone gets to have their crowning moment of awesome. It did not go leaps and bounds above my expectations, but it met them.

I'm not going to sugar-coat things just because it's the last film of a huge series (one that I would call myself a fan of too).

It's a rather disappointing end for such a prominent series. The acting was fine and what you would expect from these young adults, but all the plot seems to be in Part 1 while all the fighting seems to be in Part 2. It's no one's fault; it's just how the books had to be split up. Before watching, expect a lot of random fighting with not much plot in between. The plot that is in there is hard to follow if you haven't read the books (maybe that's why it seemed like "random fighting"). (SPOILER) I was also disppointed in the Hermione/Ron kiss. We waited how many years for that spur-of-the-moment, lack-of-passion kiss? It seemed a but rushed and out of place. But then again, it is a kid's movie, and they couldn't do much more with it. The part where Harry "dies" (or whatever he did) was cheesey and weird; I still don't understand it. The only good thing about this movie (which was earlier spoiled to me by E! News) was Snape's memory.

How can something as innocent as he started became so devastating? Preparing myself for the end of his movie saga (yes, the term applies here), I reviewed all the steps of Harry Potter on screen. I saw him learn about the wizarding world, to awaken to their true nature and, finally, understand that this world was not just made of magical adventures and challenges to be overcome, but difficult choices to be made.

Evil exists, and with it, the war was not long, bringing griefs and sorrows that come to its climax in "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2". Without reintroducing characters or situations, the film takes care to close the loose ends and further deepen the soul of those figures that we saw in our imaginations flourish in the last decade.

The story ends in a climate that can not be separated from everyday life of Europe in World War II. The World of Magic had been conquered by Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) and his supremacy. The Ministry and Hogwarts became darker versions than they were at the time that Harry lived in the closet under the stairs, becoming institutions run by fanatical followers of a totalitarian leader deranged. Harry (Radcliffe), Hermione (Watson) and Ron (Grint) have undertaken to destroy the remaining horcruxes to finally make Voldemort mortal and a tar a chance to end his reign of terror.

After a complicated stop in Gringotts, the trio discovers that a piece of the soul of Him-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named is at his old school, realizing that there will be fought the battle of their lives. A feeble resistance, but alive, persistent at Hogwarts, organizing themselves in a stronghold, the more likely a lightning strike. The faith of a whole nation under the yoke of a dictator remains deposited in Harry. The pieces are organized and the end begins.

Through stunning photography Eduardo Serra, who balances light and shadows in a way no less than spectacular, magnificent castle that follow become a battlefield in ruins and those children once ascend to heroics. Not for his prowess in combat, but by the strength of their hearts. Hearts will be broken by these losses and brutal revelation of a hitherto unknown hero, moved only by a love which, though unrequited, never ceased to exist.

Director David Yates realizes that action without emotion is something empty. From this understanding, turns the battle of Hogwarts, one of the highlights of the film, not a fireworks display, but something deeper. The director builds a whole climate of tension to the confrontation, which is announced through the powerful psychic presence of Voldemort in the minds of students and teachers of the school of magic. It is the psychological war carried to its extreme.

Goblins, witches and evil Death Eaters face the true spirit of Hogwarts amid a scene of death and destruction. Not a film for children. Beloved characters die with very little ceremony, with its absence being felt in the moments of silence, not in battle. Yates is not about the war with glamor, but with pain, as it should be addressed.

A flawless cast awards this conclusion. Daniel Radcliffe just remember the little boy who tried to spend some excitement in the beginning of the saga, Harry embodying a more secure, but which betrays moments of panic when he realized his possible fate. Of the trio, Rupert Grint was the most evolved. Careteiro a histrionic, Ron became his one true rock, even with its moments of humor. Emma Watson exudes beauty and grace as Hermione, even representing the "reason", ends up being the most passionate of the three.

Ralph Fiennes shows why he was called to incarnate Voldemort, revealing more and more of a villain in an impressive range of emotions. Even under all the makeup, the actor displays a range. When weakened, Tom Riddle becomes more frightening and unpredictable. By killing one of his henchmen for daring to speak at the wrong time, we see the anger and fear behind that gesture, not a mere crutch script to display "as the villain is bad."

Michael Gambon returns briefly as the serene Albus Dumbledore, no longer a physical presence for Harry, but his influence is felt all the time. It is worth making a digression on the omission of certain details in the film on the biography of Dumbledore in the book by JK Rowling. Cleverly, the screenplay by Steve Kloves addresses this by stating simply not applicable to the story the man who Dumbledore before Harry was to know.

And what talk of Alan Rickman? The actor, who met as the deliciously evil Hans Gruber in "Die Hard", appears only in key moments of "The Deathly Hallows - Part 2", but his appearances are real treasures. The arc of this closure Snape makes us want to review all the movies of the saga again, just so we can track every move of this true master, not only of magic but of illusion. A complex and fascinating character.

There are so many names in this veritable pantheon of British legends to leave their mark on the franchise. Maggie Smith's McGonagall shine like never before, almost a magical world of Winston Churchill. Another lady, Julie Walters, Mrs. Weasley finally see her leave the role of queen of the home and defend your children with nails and teeth and wand. John Hurt, Helena Bonham Carter, Jim Broadbent, Jason Isaacs, Gary Oldman, David Thewlis, Emma Thompson, the underrated CiarÃ¡n Hinds Abeforth emerging as Dumbledore ... A veritable "who's who" of the major representatives of the performing arts of the land of the Queen . All appear even at points in this defining moment in cinema history. No egos to be massaged.

We revisit every moment we spent together at Harry, trying again, even for a brief moment, the warmth of times past and loved ones. This heat which gives strength to go ahead and do not what is easy, but what is right. Recognize in others the sacrifice we make.

The film is still crowned by the wonderful soundtrack by Alexandre Desplat, which uses themes touched on other chapters of the saga to bring us a sense of nostalgia absolutely necessary, while it also brings us more melancholic compositions that reflect the times this final desperate act. Visual effects complement the experience breathtaking and fabulous art direction.

The epilogue makes clear that the innocence and joy are passed on through generations. Yes, we grow, but the joys of childhood linger in our children, making them eternal. That's what makes it worth all the pain of growth, knowing that one day our children can enjoy childhood as a magical and friends as faithful as those who had.

And, it ends. I cried. I admit it. But, who wouldn't if you read all The Books, watched all The Films, wrote Fanfiction about Harry Potter and His World, made HP Friends and truly became a Potterhead? Especially, watched each Character grow up throughout The Films? My Fave Scenes: 1. Ron and Hermione FINALLY *snogging*; Mrs. Weasley's showdown with Bellatrix, 'NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU B*!' and quite My Fave of all Faves: Voldemort laughing at The End. I cannot stop laughing at that scene and I will never forget how funny it looks with Voldemort trying to be a cheery bloke, when we know exactly who he is. Well, looking forward to new Book Releases, Film Premieres and HP Parties are over; but, HP will forever live on. As long as you are loyal to him. The best way to think of Deathly Hallows Part 2 is the finale of an eight part saga (obviously).  Don't expect new, groundbreaking revelations about the characters or any more  emotional depth than we've had in the previous seven films.  Rather, all the previous pieces come together for this two hour visual effects extravaganza.  DH2 doesn't need to reinvent the HP wheel and it doesn't try to. "Harry Potter" saves the best for last

	It's hard to believe that is was decade ago I was going to see the first "Harry Potter" movie with my friends, give or take a few months, and I had been reading the books for at least a year prior to that. It has certainly been a very long journey from then until now, but here in 2011 the "Harry Potter" film series has finally reached its conclusion, and, as completely expected, ends on the finest note possible. 
"Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2" combines the perfect mix of true adaptation, and original ingenuity, brining the unique voice of the films to an amazing conclusion, while still providing a familiar story to those who have read the books.
	The film begins precisely where the first part left off. Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson) have just escaped Voldemort, once again at the cost of a life of, this time Harry's house-elf friend Dobby. The trio is on the trail of the last of the dark lord Voldemort's (Ralph Fiennes) Horcruxes, parts of his splintered soul he secreted away into objects in order to attain immortality. After an eventful bank robbery at the beginning of the film, the three return to Hogwarts for the final pieces of the puzzle and the ultimate last battle against the forces of darkness.
	If there are any viewers out there who might have though the pacing in the first part of "The Deathly Hallows" was a bit slow, then you'll be happy to hear that the second part is a non-stop action-packed, emotionally charged roller coaster from start to finish. The tone is dark, the action is much more brutal and the stakes are higher than ever. 
Not everyone is coming out of the fight alive, and the film does a very good job of not pulling its punches and showing just how much this battle is going to cost. There are quite a few moments that bring a lump to the throat or tear to the eye, especially for those of us who have grown up with these stories and movies for half our lives, There are considerably fewer moments of levity, even compared to the first part, but this is for the best, considering the events taking place are incredibly serious.
	Because the second part focuses almost entirely on the Battle of Hogwarts, it gives the secondary characters that were barely in the first part a chance to shine as well. Alan Rickman (Professor Snape), Maggie Smith (Professor McGonagall) and Matthew Lewis (Neville Longbottom) all pull off memorable performances, and they're just he tip of the iceberg. 
Almost every significant character from the earlier films is a part of the action here, and it really helps cash in on the nostalgic qualities at play. After all, this is something a decade in the making, and it truly pays off on an emotion and sentimental level.
	As always, the acting of every person involved from the main characters to the supporting cast is superb. The writing, which has given the films a unique voice of their own, continues to impress here, invoking all of the right emotions and keeping the tone and pacing in perfect sync. The special effects, as always were spectacular, but the visuals were particular striking this time around, particularly as the Hogwarts professors cast powerful protective charms over the castle.   I did not see the film in 3D, and frankly, after seeing the film in the regular two dimensions, I can tell you it's just as impressive, and cheaper.
	There honestly isn't a single thing I can complain about here. Every omission from the book was perfectly justified in my eyes, and considering this film only covers what amounts to the last fourth of it means very little is missing, anyway. Any complaints I would say would be mere nitpicking at this point, and this film certainly doesn't warrant that.
	The icing on the cake is the unfathomable box office results: over $168 million in a single weekend.  That knocks "The Dark Knight" off the number one pedestal, and most pundits did not think the results would be this monstrous.
	Simply put, "Deathly Hallows Part 2" is one of the finest "epic" films I've seen. It's right up there with "Return of the King" in my opinion. It's one of those films people will remember for decade to come. Not only because of the cultural significance of "Harry Potter" as a whole, but because over the past ten years these films have taken on their own life, apart from the literature itself. Never in the history of film has a single narrative been continued for over 18 hours.  Chances are, it may never be again.
They are connected, but still separate. It is that uniqueness that makes the films so appealing, even to those very familiar with the stories already. I once again tip my metaphorical hat to writer Steve Kloves and director David Yates, who I grew to like over his tenure at the head of this franchise, for doing such fantastic work with the series. And while it may be a bit bittersweet to say goodbye to so long-running a franchise, I think we're so much the better for the journey taken.
Grade: A
Entertainment Value: 10

These days movie franchises rarely come to a climactic end. I mean, Lord of the Rings was supposed to end with Return of the King, but now there's going to be three prequels. Star Wars was supposed to stop with Return of the Jedi, but now they're talking about a THIRD trilogy of movies. Harry Potter is one of those few exceptions, and for the ending we get most certainly the most well-made and exciting movies of them all that ends on an incredibly strong note that I'm sure had many fans actually crying with the fact that it was over. 

     Deathly Hallows Part 2 doesn't waste too much time in getting started. The exciting break-in to Gringotts to destroy another one of Voldemort's horcruxes occurs within less than the movie's first half-hour. From there the pace accelerates even farther as they go back to Hogwarts for the final battle. This film shows why the final book had to be split into two movies. It rockets forward at an amazing pace to get everything done in a satisfying way; there is no filler here. 

     What makes this movie awesome for me is all the set pieces, whether they be involved in the Battle of Hogwarts or not. We have the awesome mine cart roller coaster through Gringotts, a cool but brief return of the Chamber of Secrets, an exploding bridge, the fiery room of requirement, and a truly awesome battle within the court yard of the school. Speaking of the battle, I give the movie credit in that I actually understood what was going on in the different parts of the castle as the huge fight took place, even if the main characters don't participate in much of the fighting (though they do more so than in the book). 

     If there are a few tiny flaws I have, it's that I would have liked the final, final showdown between Harry and Voldemort to be a little bit longer. Considering everything in the last seven and three quarters movies have been leading up to this, I thought it should have been drawn out a bit more. I'm not going to dock any points since it's still a pretty awesome ending, but I was just hoping for a bit more. Also, I don't think it's much of a spoiler to say several characters die. However, the majority of these deaths happen off-screen, and I would have liked to see what had happened. Once again, this is just nitpicking (especially since it was the same way in the book), but it was just something I would be interested in seeing. 

     Everything culminates here with just about every character remaining getting a least a brief cameo in the battle. It's an amazing finale that is far and away the best movie of 2011. Even if you found your interest sagging during the fifth or sixth installments, this one makes it all worth it.

An epic conclusion to an epic franchise. I think the Harry Potter movies are the best series (of movies) that has been made to date, with the exception of the Lord of the Rings trilogy. Part 2 feels like only half a movie. All the edge of your seat action is packed into this two hour finale. I will enjoy once it hits DVD and I can watch Part 1 with it, because together they will be pure epicness.

âUnprecedentedâ? and âepic.â?  Terms that are attributed far too casually in todayâ(TM)s pop culture but remain the embodiment of what the tale of âthe boy who livedâ? has accomplished over the past decade.  But no matter how amazing, how grand or at what heights a saga can climb, it will only ever be as strong as its climatic conclusion.  This is the heavy burden carried by Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows:  Part 2.

Resuming very near the instant where Deathly Hallows Part 1 closed, Harry, Hermione and Ron continue on their mission to destroy the remaining horcruxes of Lord Voldemort in an effort to make him vulnerable.  With very little to go on and still piecing together the significance of the Deathly Hallows, the trio make their way back to Hogwarts to confront the now Headmaster Snape and take back the school.  With each horcrux Harry destroys, Voldemort becomes more unhinged and he sets out to kill Harry once and for all.

Director David Yates (Deathly Hallows Part 1, Half-Blood Prince, Order of the Phoenix) masterfully and slowly gradients his way out from the jarring, ominous tone he set in Deathly Hallows Part 1.  Largely due to the main three characters emerging from their seclusion and the reappearance of the very important supporting cast, including the Hogwarts School itself.  Even in its dark state, seeing the school again was extremely comforting after the manic transgressions of Deathly Hallows Part 1.  Which may be where some reviews of âPart 1â? were slightly short sighted, present writer slightly culpable.  The exclusion of Harry from his friends, teachers and the school in âPart 1â? is an integral component of what makes âPart 2â? so powerful, but even more important, it may be the key to fully understanding one of the dullest, interesting, vanilla, complex characters ever created, Harry Potter himself. 

Iâ(TM)m going to break my own rule of not writing in the first person for this review.  Much like a narrator in a film like The Shawshank Redemption or Fight Club, the tactic only works if it truly adds depth and meaning that could not be achieved otherwise.  I feel the need for this because I now believe that I have been something that I definitely do not like to admit being.  That thing would be âwrong.â?  Iâ(TM)ve been wrong about the character of Harry Potter for seven films.  Iâ(TM)ve had expectations that I had no right to presume, Iâ(TM)ve been advocating and petitioning for this character to act in a way he was never meant to act.  I was not alone in my frustrations, and I take zero responsibility, no way, of course not.  I was tricked, bamboozled, run amuck, led astray.  I didnâ(TM)t land on Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, Hogwarts landed on me!  The realization that Iâ(TM)ve been so wrong is what sets the Potter "chosen one" saga apart from all others.  Not because Iâ(TM)m a âknow it all,â? although that accusation has been cast my way more than a few times, but because being wrong about Harry, putting pressure on him, waiting for him to do something that is completely beyond his abilities, is exactly what the character feels in the story.  Iâ(TM)m just another outsider, thinking this boy is âthe chosen one,â? waiting for his legend to come to fruition and defeat an all-powerful dark lord.  Harry Potter is not Neo nor is he Luke Skywalker.  He is simply a boy who was born into an impossible situation, trying to save the world even though he has no business doing so.  This is not to say Harry lacks special abilities above all others as it becomes quite clear in this film why he has been so often compared to his mother Lily throughout the series.

Aside from the great storytelling, witty dialogue, and perfect chemistry youâ(TM)d expect from actors that have been on the same job together for a decade, there are two standout performances in this finale.  No, itâ(TM)s not the nervous courage of Daniel Radcliffe as Harry or the immersive hopelessness once again perfected by Ralph Fiennes as Voldemort, this time around its Rupert Grintâ(TM)s Ron and Alan Rickmanâ(TM)s Snape who exhibit the welcome evolution of a stronger and a vulnerable side respectively at symphonic moments in the story arc.

Deathly Hallows Part 2 also embraces a much grander Return of the King or Return of the Jedi experience, but makes sure to still spotlight smaller characters, which are so important to the drive behind Harryâ(TM)s purpose.  A good portion of the plot focuses on revealing the answers to many of the questions that fans who have only seen the films have had for many years, but the script is able to incorporate them into the story naturally to avoid feelling like a Wizarding World version of "This Is Your Life."  Readers of the books, who will undoubtedly tell you every single thing that was left out or changed whether you elicit the information from them or not, should also be very fulfilled.  Of course thatâ(TM)s taking into account they have enough inherent logic to comprehend if the films were a direct transcript of the books, we would still be awaiting the release of âHarry Potter and the Goblet of Fire: Part 3.â?

So with the triumph of Deathly Hallows Part 2, the question can finally be seriously debated, is the "Harry Potter Saga" the greatest film franchise of all time?  Perhaps, perhaps not.  Itâ(TM)s not really a question that would have had a definite answer whether this film emulated The Empire Strikes Back or Howard The Duck.  The real achievement is that the franchise is now in the argument.  Although, during such discussions an ironic parallel will undoubtedly and maybe even unknowingly be drawn to its title character.  Against titans like Star Wars, Indiana Jones, Rocky, and The Godfather, advocates of Harry Potter will shout at the top of their lungs that it is easily the greatest film saga of all time and cannot be defeated.  Detractors will claim the âPotterâ? films have no business being uttered in the same breath as those franchises.  Others may even placate that they are greatly misunderstood, or say that they had so much potential to be greater than they are. 

Before this film, if I had heard an argument such as that I would have aligned myself with one of those facets and fought for it vehemently.  Now I would simply say . . .

Well....what a crushing disappointment! Yet, its the second highest rated! Basically, I came in expecting a masterpiece. The ratings were exceptionally high and my hype was through the roof. But things picked up toward the end, and I was moved by some parts, even if I found the film be a massive disappointment. Its better than the first 6, but not its immediate predecessor. This film should have been longer, and it should have had more character moments like the first. I am glad that the series ended on a stronger note than its dismal middle entrees. I would have to give the film franchise an 8/10. For the most part, it doesn't succeed in capturing what made the books so special, it just translates them to the screen. It all ends here. After a very suitable and coincidental 9 and 3-quarter years, the journey of Harry Potter has finally come to an end. The story for Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 is fantastic and the decision to split Deathly Hallows in half was the correct decision as both parts stay very faithful to the book, not changing or leaving a lot missed out. Not only is the story loyal to the books but it's also gripping as well as there are quite a few scenes that will have you on the edge of your seats, especially some scenes involving Severus Snape, portrayed by Alan Rickman. The performances from the cast are fantastic and it's very easy to say that in this movie, the acting is the best out of the lot. Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint were brilliant as their characters but the best performance has definitely got to go to Alan Rickman, who plays Severus Snape. There's a specific scene in the movie which involves him that is guaranteed that there won't be a dry eye in the house. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 weren't short on special effects and believe it when you hear that the effects were very impressive from Hogwarts Castle to the creatures to the spectacular fights.

Although Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 wasn't shot in 3D, the 3D worked very well and wasn't underused or overused. The 3D was used in such a way that it wasn't gimmicky where many things jumped out of the screen at you to make you remember you're watching it in 3D but it was great to see scenes such as the Gringotts Bank scene and The Battle of Hogwarts. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 has some fantastic moments and the special effects were used brilliantly. The story has some solid moments and even some emotional scenes, which may bring a tear to your eye. The direction was fantastic as all of the scenes in the movie were very well done and you really cared about all of the characters in the movie. Overall, if you can, watch this in 3D. Many people will disagree with this and will say that it doesn't add anything but The Battle of Hogwarts is very well done and considering Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2is post-production 3D, it's great.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2brings the series to a fantastic end and not only that, this movie is the best out of all of them. It's more magical, more dark and very gripping and emotional. However, be warned, this isn't a movie to take anyone below the age of ten to see. It's sad to see the series go after almost ten years but it's ends on a brilliant high. Well done to all of the cast and crew, you've done a marvellous job on making fans happy and bringing the boy wizard to life on screen.

The consensus seems to be that the Harry Potter series saved the best until last; and I'm not going to argue - my opinion is that, yes, this is the best of the series... however, The Deathly Hallows Part II is hardly a classic, which should tell you something of the mediocrity of the entire series as well as give an insight into current pop culture.

The "Twilight" phenomenon, for lack of a better term, also applies to this series of films.  That they all were a commercial success is more a nod towards rabid fanaticism then one towards stellar filmmaking (although I will admit that this last film had some wonderfully seamless CGI).

I believe part of the issue here is that the books were so well loved - to the point where there are fans who know every bit character and would be disappointed if even the smallest of characters didn't receive his time in front of the lens.  While this over the top fandom is nice (and certainly didn't hurt the bottom line of the film franchise), it hampered all of the films.  Far too often a character would do what amounted to a walk on - often regardless of the pacing or situation of the film - just to satisfy the book freaks.  For a couple of examples: Helena Bonham Carter's Bellatrix.  She makes a nice appearance in Hallows part I, but then isn't really involved in part II at all (does she even have a speaking line at all, or do anything except cackle before being blown to bits? - and for this Carter gets major billing right below the 3 stars - wow!).  Further, Maggie Smith is mere window dressing throughout all of the films until this last (as if to say - see, aren't we cool, we've got Maggie Smith in our films).  But low and behold, Dame Smith finally gets to do something in part II - which is yet another reason why this one rises above the rest.  It is full Maggie when she animates the guard gargoyles to protect Hogwart and then turns to an associate and admits with that so proper, yet with a gleam in her eye tone, "I've always wanted to do that spell".

In speaking about Part II in particular; as I've noted, the CGI is wonderful, the acting shows depth, as the main characters, especially Harry, have grown into the roles quite nicely.  Alan Rickman is the usual perfect Snape, and Ralph Fiennes does a nice job of voice emoting through the mask of "you know who".  I thought the pacing was good for the most part, though once again a bit too much attention was lavished on bit players (a tighter narrative for the whole series could have been achieved with the judicious exclusion of several characters).  Personally, I rather enjoyed the White Train Station sequence (where Harry may or may not be dead).  I just wish the White Room at the station had black curtains - and so would Jack Bruce, I'm sure.  The conversation between Dumbledore and Harry contains a nice bit of metaphysics - Harry asks Dumbledore if this is all in his mind and Dumbledore replies, "of course it is - which doesn't mean that it isn't also happening in real life".

Really, my only major complaint in this final chapter is tag ending, which is totally superfluous and adds nothing to the story other than a happy ending (yet another bit of pandering to the perceived audience, I'm sure).  The film would have been far better served to have concluded with the three friends (perhaps echoing the triangle that was the driving force for the entire series) standing on the bridge to the ruined Hogwart and, with backs turned from it, looking with determination towards the future.

The epic ending to an era. For ten years and eight movies, I have waited for this cinematic masterpiece and the wait was well worth it.  Deathly Hallows Part 2 truly captures the essence that is Harry Potter. The action and visual effects are beyond incredible and we are kept on the edge of seats the entire time. Each character has at least one moment where they can shine. The final and long awaited battle between Harry and Voldemort is extremely intense and heart stopping. I don't think I breathed once during that scene.  Ever since Sorcerer's Stone, Harry Potter has been a huge part of my life, and I might sound very nerdy, but the best part of my life so far was watching as Harry realized he could end Voldemort's tyranny once and for all and he cast that golden wall of energy that caused Voldemort's killing curse to rebound upon him. There will never be another movie series like Harry Potter and there will never be another finale movie like this one here. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 is by far my absolute favorite movie and nothing will ever take it's place. Let the magic continue to endure even though the series has come to an end.

-    The movie starts EXACTLY where Part 1 ended. 

-    Why does Ron always look stoned?

After over ten years of movie magic, our most lucrative film series casts its final spell. This war film is a noble and surprisingly brisk end to an elaborate tale told better in the beloved books. That being said, Hallows: Part Two ranks up with the better Potter films: Goblet of Fire and Half-Blood Prince.

Harry and his friends still search for a way to destroy Evil Lord Voldermort. The Dark Lord has separated his soul into several pieces-doodads called horcruxes-to make himself immortal. If Team Harry can destroy the horcruxes, they can kill Voldermort. It all ends where it began-in a massive, metaphysical (and slightly cheesy) battle at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

After the klutzy storytelling and inexperienced acting of the first two films, the creative team slowly found their talents; the emotional depth here rivals the better moments of the other seven films. The film still disapparates from one plot point to another, but the approach has grown less awkward. Heartfelt moments are given their final, grave weight in a way that most of the other films missed. After the aimlessness of Hallows: Part One, this second half is thrillingly succinct.

Still, certain important points still seem deathly hollow. The final fights just feel like they should've been bigger, more epic, with more witnesses. However, overall, Hallows: Part Two is a genuine finale to a story filled with immense love and wonder.

I'm holding my hand up and bowing my head in shame. 

You see, I've never read a Harry Potter book. What's worse is that at the same time I've taken the mickey out of those that did read them ... and I've really enjoyed the movies. Utterly hypocritical? Yes.  This evening I watched the story end in spectacular style as all the threads were tied together, explaining to those of us too stupid/lazy to read the books why things happened as they did. 

As it unfolded I was gripped by the tension, wowed by the special effects (even in 2D the effects are stunning) but above all else, I felt an emotional connection with the story. The last time I experienced this feeling was during Return of the King and it's story telling / movie making like this that I absolutely love ... and am going to miss badly. 

I've been told that I want too much from the movies that I watch; that I complain too much about some of the dross that I'm expected to pay for. However, you simply cannot compare movies like Transformers or the Pirates series against the Potter movies. In fact, it hurts me to mention these monumental disapointments in the same paragraph as the Potter series. HP7B is not going to be the best or my favourite film of 2011 but it, along with all the others in the series, will always have a place in my heart as being a wonderful story turned into amazing cinematography. 

Thank you JK Rowling. Thank you Warner Brothers. I was wrong and I'm sorry; the Harry Potter series has been hugely enjoyable and I'm sorry its all over.

The final Harry Potter movie plays like a feverish attempt to answer all your questions, satisfy all your desires, and give you everything you've waited years for.  This would often be a complaint in art for me, as it always feels vaguely fake for a director to feed me exactly what I'm expecting out of a film, but here, it's the only possible solution.  Harry Potter has certainly been about the good struggling with darkness, and like most other stories following the hero cycle, it's difficult to say that it should end in a dark place.  Dark things happen, and by the end there is typically a lot of sacrifice, but the hero must overcome.  That's what we get here, and Yates gives it to us brilliantly.  I will defend to the death that he is the best thing that ever happened to the Harry Potter franchise.  He knows when a film needs silence.  He knows when a film needs a long fight scene.  He knows how to build a scene around small details and focus the camera in just the right way that you can have an important foreground and background.  He knows when to have an extreme close up on someone's face, and when it's necessary for a ton of space on screen.  He knows when to part with his characteristic neutral colors to serve the story.  Just like the book, the most unfortunate part of this film is the epilogue.  It beats you over the head with a bunch of stuff you knew already, capitalizing on cheap sentimentality and making the full circle theme even more obvious.  Aside from that, and a botched line or two from Daniel Radcliffe, this is a great adaptation.  Considering the source material, I think Yates made changes that better serve the story, frankly, and he filled every important moment with the necessary emotion, darkness, and beauty that it deserves.  Well done.

There's so much to say about this film, ten years worth in fact. This film made many landmarks in cinema history. When you think about how much dedication the cast and crew had to make eight consistent films, it's quite apalling. I must say that the film ended the series beautifully, making many moments more poignant that the books did. We've watched many actors literally age and improve in their acting. The three leads have come a long way in their acting, and their efforts should be applauded here. The film transcends the young adult genre. David Yates' finale to the series gives it an epic bang. There is plenty of dark material in this film. The weight that the three leads carry on their shoulder is incredible. This film obviously has the most action in the series, but also has very intimate scenes, some with a near film noir feel to them. Ralph Fiennes accomplished for Voldemort what the novels did: nearly making me feel sorry for him. Ralph embodies Voldemort scarily well, showing emotions in the character that haven't ever been witnessed. Snape's tragic end is beautifully captured by Alan Rickman. His knowledge of the character runs so deep and it is noticed so well in this film. The special effects and cinematography are incredible, the detail in crafting them astounding when meticulously observed. The action in the film was epic without feeling overblown. Everyone involved in the film wanted the franchise to end in the best way possible and I think they achieved just that. Whine if you want about the epilogue, but I think it was handled in the best possible way. The film kept me engaged from beginning to end and was one of the most enthralling cinema experiences I have ever had. Watching the series make its final mark in cinematic history was an event that I will remember and cherish for many years to come.

Previously on 'Reviewing Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows'...

'Deathly Hallows is a tome of a children's novel.'

'Where the Hell do you get off? You dick!'

'Grumpy teenager of a film.'

'The Nick Cave bit...'

'The Boy Who Lived...'

'This'll be the best Christmas Walford has ever seen.'



Excuse the theatrics, but I'm just doing what Deathly Hallows Part 2 refuses to do. Give the casual viewer a catch-up on Part 1. Nope. David Yates makes sure we hit the ground running. And by running, I mean mumbling for 20 minutes in a beach side cottage, but my point stands.

My previous review gives the sensation that I'm not a Harry Potter fan. Trust me, I am. My problem with the films is that they are so uneven. I genuinely only count three as being actually any good. Part 2 is one of those. Following the threat of more walking, Part 2 really picks up the minute we get to Diagon Alley and, from that point, very rarely lets up.

There's a sense of maturity to this film that has definitely been missing from the others. It's hard to put my finger on what makes me think this, which is pretty useless for a film review I know. The direction is right, the mood is right and the jokes are right. It gives me that warm fuzzy feeling I get when I watch 80s movies from my childhood.

One could go on all day about how out three protagonists work so well together, but mention should be made of Alan Rickman. A ten minute series of flashbacks showing Snape's part in Harry's life enforces the reasons why Rickman was chosen for more than just looking like an elderly Trent Reznor.

The climatic battle at Hogwarts is bloody without being too dark; a good blend of one-liners prevent it from being too bogged down in its own emo-ness. It's structured so that, whilst long, you don't lose your bearings among the chaos.

So, with all the Potter love I'm spewing, you're probably wondering if there is actually anything wrong with it. Well, yes. The attempt to throw in numerous cameos from the previous seven films does distract from the action on screen.

'Oh no! He's dead. I can't believe it... Wait, is that Jim Broadbent? It is! Oh, and there's Miriam Margoyles!'

A big special mention has to be made to the ending... I've mentioned my disdain for the epilogue from the book so my heart truly sank when they decided to include it in Part 2. It's awful. It's like watching pre-schoolers raiding mummy's wardrobe so they can play dress up. CGI was not invented for this. Yes, it was put in there to appease the hardcore fans, but so were the multiple endings of 'Return of the King'. That didn't make any more fucking right.

Long story short, Part 2 finishes the series on a high and I'm sure that Warner Brothers are happy. Now, let's remake all Chris Columbus's contributions and we may be onto something...

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 is a more than suitable climatic film of what is fair to say is a spellbinding franchise' I myself have grown up with the Magical World of Potter and I have to say it has been a pleasure to have done so.

Since Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was released in 2001 Chris Columbus, Alfonso Cuaron, Mike Newell and David Yeates (present) have put together a fabulous collection of books written by J.K Rowling onto the big screen and they have done a superb job of doing it. There is no doubt that 90% of the credit should be rewarded to Rowling for her outstanding writing but just like with Eragon, a good book does not mean the film will be entertaining.

It has been an enormously long race but now it comes to an end; Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, Rupert Grint and co are set to bid farewell to Hogwarts in what is likely to be an emotional farewell for the cast and crew. Oh yes sorry, the last film wasn't bad either!

Harry (Radcliffe), Ron (Grint) and Hermione (Watson) continue in their quest to search for the missing Horcrux's in what proves to begin from the climax or there abouts of Deathly Hallows Part 1. After a brief few minutes of dialogue the action kicks off when Harry breaks into Gringots Bank of Wizard's via the assistance of a goblin who then leaves them for dead whilst inside when a fire breathing dragon realises of their presence. However, the trio manage to escape and are soon back in the mix when they realise Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) is on to them and is out to kill them, most notably the dark wizard wants to murder Potter who he correctly sees as the main threat.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 is a very good movie and a more than suitable climax to a fantastic franchise - it is not perfect!

The moment that the whole collection of movies have been building up to is a final stand off between both Harry and Voldemort. Unfortunately, director David Yeates decides to ditch the book's version of events for the highly hyped battle which wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing; however it is over within minutes and it is a huge disappointment in my point of view.

Also, numerous characters did not have their moments of glory. Bellatrix Lestrange (Helena Bonham Carter) had only small cameo roles in the film and again was involved in a very short battle of her own which again proved rather frustrating. 

However, it may not be a perfect ending but Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 is still an excellent finale for fans. Although I have not given a five star rating for any of the films due to the fact that the majority of them have a similar feel, I do have to say that as a long lasting franchise which is thoroughly entertaining in each chapter, it gets top marks!

The final entry in the Harry Potter film franchise is a fantastic close-out to the series. The positives about it are the score, the overall tone & feel, the performances and the look. I particularly liked the quiet opening to set the stage for things to come... to get louder. The only drawback is that this is a Part 2 film, and as I stated in my review of Part 1, all of this should have all been in one film. An hour or more could have been cut out of both parts to tell a more proper story. The first part drags out and winds down to nothing while this film gets into the real meat of things and ramps everything up to its conclusion. I would say that this could be the second-best film in the series, but I might have to reflect on that in the coming years being that it's still fresh in my mind. Regardless, the series has ended well and it goes out with a very good send-off.

Well that was anticlimactic. Here for once you have this massive large-scale epic, full of revelations and twists and action, and the movie cut most of it out? How incredibly dumb. Moments that everyone loved in the book are here lazily thrown in, almost as if you hear Yates complaining, "Do I have to?". Others are cut completely for no worthwhile reason, and entire plot revelations that cast much of the series in a new light in the books are also gone. What you're left with is a short and mostly unseen battle scene, a final fight that no longer makes any real sense or impact, and a hilarious makeup-job ending.

It's not all bad, as the first half of the movie is actually pretty good at depicting hollowed-out versions of events from the book... but this strange, toned-down filmmaking has left me wondering if, years from now, anybody will really remember the Harry Potter films particularly fondly. I can't help but feel that they will never be the classics they could've been.

Deathly Hallows part 2 ends this well produced saga with tremendous grace and a beautifully orchestrated climax that I am sure will satisfy both lovers of the books and films.If you have read the books as I have you will be glad to know major key moments are intact. Much is missing but I won't dwell on that, no point, its how well this movie plays out and for me it rolls wonderfully between excitement, thrills and emotional drama towards a satisfactory (though a slightly rushed) conclusion. There are at least 2 sequences so powerful that I defy anyone not to at least stifle a tear or choke a little. One of those sequence is an exquisitely executed flashback that is pivotal to the whole story. I have to say, that despite the woes we book readers have when elements (big chunks of it too) are omitted from the movies, much credit still has to go to Steve Kloves for adapting the books for the big screen, cleverly weaving, changing and even adding new big elements to give a kinetic flow to the narrative and here it all comes together superbly.David Yates assured direction has nurtured our young actors in the last 4 films to blossom into even more adept actors who convey their characters with natural tones without overacting. Daniel Radcliffe had to carry this movie more than any other and has done so brilliantly complemented with great support from his two companions, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint.Pretty much all the characters we have met in all the movies have made an appearance in this finale but one actor stands out, Alan Rickman. His portrayal of Professor Snape has always been a joy to watch (if a little novel) but here his scenes will leave a dramatic engraving in my memory. Here he elevates his portrayal of one of the most complex character in young adult literature to an unforgettable piercingly emotional one.Another actor who really shines in the few scenes that he has, is Matthew Lewis as Neville Longbottom who we see gradually transforming over the past films from the clumsy bullied boy to a brave warrior in this final film. Many other British thespians of the series also have their few moments to shine especially Maggie Smith's Professor McGonagal who was a delight to watch as she takes charge of the defence of Hogwarth School.As for the spectacle of the battle and showdowns, while not at the scale of Lord of the Rings, I honestly cant think how it could have been done better as the film makers have intertwined heart stopping action with dramatic progressions in the narrative. Its actually more visceral and dynamic than the rather smaller scale battle of the brilliant novels (not to take anything away from Rowling's writing). Do I have any gripes? Yes I do. Although I applaud Steve Kloves for a difficult screenplay adaption...I think he could still have done better at explaining some odd anomalies that only readers of the book will understand. This might annoy you if you haven't read the books. But its a small gripe because what we get is delightful.What an amazing achievement to faithfully bring Rowling's epic saga to the big screen with the same cast and largely the same crew, maintaining the brilliant quality right to the end.

Minus a few artistic liscenses, this films manages to capture the imagination of fans of the books. While unable to show the final battle in its entirety, this film managed to raise the stakes so high that the conclusion was more than satisfying. With evil finally vanquished and the next generation starting their journey, this film was a perfect end to a series that defined generation.

The perfect book series is matched with the perfect movie series in J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter universe. With every character being so dynamic and each having flaws only real people could helm, the magic is relentlessly absent without the heart and soul brought to every character through pen or person. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson change lives with something more than a performance. Deathly hallows part 2 is the luminescent beacon of cinema storytelling and the epic, emotionally vibrant, heart stopping experience that is Harry Potter.

Why do you people delude yourselves into thinking that these movies were good? Is it because you have such a steadfast loyalty and love for the books? Do you focus on the small/rare bits of humor and emotion that stumble accidentally into each film and convince yourself that they can make up for all their other deficiencies? If that's the case you are trying too hard to love a movie that neither warrants it, nor deserves it.  The HP films are a stale and poorly-made representation of a fantastic and wonderful story.  Deathly hallows was no exception; The plot was rushed and not fully-developed, summed up by a random youtuber's comment when he/she asked "So....How/why did Voldemort die??".  Dan was as stiff as ever, Emma was predictably over the top, and the few decent actors in the film gave empty performances due to the incompetence of Yates' lack of artistic and directorial vision.   The cinematography was noticeably decent, though it sacrificed shot continuity in the process.  Ultimately the best thing they did was to take an excerpt of the music from the first HP film (composed by HP's TRUE composer John Williams) to use as the farewell score for the finale of the series.  Yet even this was not done properly, as Yates' choice of shots did very little justice to the power and beauty of the music.  For myself and others, this so-called satisfying conclusion really came with Hagrid being applauded in the Great Hall at the end of Chamber of Secrets, before the "magic" of the HP films began on its downward spiral.

After 10 years of growing up with Harry and his friends... it finally comes to an end.  Saying I had REALLY REALLY HIGH expectations coming into this movie would be a complete understatement. I have followed this franchise almost religiously, and I have to say... I was a little bit disappointed with how everything was wrapped up and concluded.  I told myself beforehand that I was not going to spoil myself by reading any of the books... so that I would have a better chance of being sucked into the movie. However, as I continued to re-watch this movie, I began to take on a different viewpoint. 

I took on a more voyeuristic viewpoint and sadly that made me more critical on this film. For 8 films we have been drawn into the mythology that is Harry Potter... and for 8 films we have been waiting for the climactic battle between him and Voldemort.  I felt like had I been in Harry's shoes... I would have at least had SOME kind of dialogue with Voldemort before zapping him away... or vice versa. Here is the boy who lived... one of your Horcruxes... and you can't conjure up any words to say to him at the very end?  I mean I didn't see this movie in 3D... so his 'flaking away' style death wasn't really all that great to me... but I felt like the final battle could have been a lot better... and a lot of things could have been said that would have concluded things better. 

The music was excellent of course; as expected of the Harry Potter franchise. I did feel like some of the music repeated itself... or at least had the same tone to it. For example, when an epic fight is taking place... you would hear a lot of 'boom boom boom' from the drums... and that, at least to me, was a tad bit distracting. My other complaint would have to be the battles involving the students of Hogwarts.  They could have at least shown individual battles with some of the minor characters... so we aren't left guessing as to what happened to them... or if they got stronger/smarter/craftier over the 8 years. 

I do love the religious elements that are found throughout the 8 films though. The whole "Good vs. Evil" story line between Harry and Voldemort fits this theme very well... and Harry has that 'self-sacrificing for the sake of humanity' mentality through the 8 movies... which is an allusion to Christ sacrificing Himself to save us.

All in all, this was a good movie on its own. But I felt like it left too much out.... especially as the 8th and final movie that was 'supposedly' the one that wrapped everything up. That is why I'm giving this movie 4 stars.

[Spoiler Alert]

First, the caveat, I have not read the books.  It is possible the director decided to create these movies with an assumption that the viewer was familiar with the books.  If so, the following complaints are largely moot.  Even so, here are my off-the-top-of-my-head comments.

While all the films progress rather well, and over all they are fairly well executed, I must say, the final films didn't wrap up very neatly.  Unanswered questions are fine when there is an expectation of another film, but not when you know it's the last one(s).  

For example, little is done with the deathly hallows themselves, and they seem to take a back burner to the horcruxes.  Except for the wand, they aren't really needed.  Also, how did Harry's dad come by the cloak - assuming it was the deathly hallow cloak.  How did Albus come by the wand and the stone of resurrection; and why drop the stone and leave it in the forest.  (Further, since the cloak was given to Harry by Albus, that means he had all three at one point, which would have made him master of death for a time.)  There appears to be no attempt by Voldemort to obtain the items - other than the wand - and why would Harry tell Voldemort that the wand's allegiance might be to someone else?  The wand's allegiance was a nice twist, but why tell?  And why break the wand? Why keep the cloak (unless it was lost in the vault)?  Albus didn't seem to think it all that dangerous to keep them all.

Why did Harry grab Voldemort and throw them both into the chasm?  The resulting flying-smoke-trip fight was rather interesting from a special effects point of view, but not exactly necessary.   

The Severus-Lilly patronus connection wasn't quite clear to me.  

If Severus was the Half-Blood Prince, was he half Muggle blood?  If so, why would Voldemort have accepted him into his circle?  It's implied that Severus had been in league with V for some time, surely, he would have known.  Would killing Albus have been enough to make such an exception?  

How did Neville know about the sword in Hermione's bag?  

The more I think about it, the more I see huge holes in the story.  It seems a great opportunity was missed to tie up a lot of little things that have been seen throughout the series into one extremely satisfying singularity, but instead, they opted for something more pedestrian.  Perhaps they should have followed Jackson's lead with Lord Of The Rings and planned on a Deluxe DVD edition with extended / extra scenes.  

Then again, perhaps I just missed the connections.

From the sensational start to the emotional end, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows part 2 is a truly spellbinding film. Continuing from where the previous left off, the plot follows Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger attempting to complete the seemingly impossible task of eliminating the threat of the sinister Lord Voldemort. 
Since the release of the magical novel in 2007, fans have been eagerly anticipating the release of the film adaptation. The question is, did it live up to their expectations? Speaking as a Potter fan myself, it soared above and beyond them! The quality of the film justifies the action of splitting the book into two, something which was questioned by many. However, by doing this, the true essence of the novel is captured, and the intricate plot line is depicted faultlessly depicted on screen. 
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows follows the three heroes; Harry, Ron and Hermione on their quest to fulfil the task set by their deceased headmaster, Dumbledore. As the film progresses, suspense is gradually built up, as the audience are constantly haunted by the knowledge that "neither can live while the other survives". As always in the world of Potter, nothing goes to plan, filling the plot with twists, turns and jaw dropping revelations which leave the audience on the edge of their seats, keeping them guessing until the very end.  The epilogue lasts a mere five minutes. However, the transfer from page to screen is flawless, allowing the series to end just as perfectly as it began. 
The heart-warming thing about the Harry Potter films is not only the powerful yet age old message of how good triumphs over evil, but how we have watched the three actors mature and develop alongside their characters. Daniel Radcliffe is not a shadow of the little boy who everyone sympatheised with. He has grown up to be a complex, confident, courageous character; its just a pity he waited until the last instalment to display his true acting abilities! This is displayed particulally in the scene in which he encounters everyone he has lost in his past. His emotion put a lump in everyones throats! Rupert Grint is no longer simply the comic sidekick. Although certain scenes bring a lightness to the dark story , several are spilling over with emotion and grief. This is seen in particular when he finds a member of his family lay dead, and is unable to control his anguish. The stunning Emma Watson has completely transformed from the precocious child we met in the first film. Throughout the series, Watson has been labelled as the more capable of the trio. This talent shines through in this project too. Her portrayal of Hermione brings a depth of maturity, and an understanding of multifaceted relationships. This is highlighted in the epilogue, where she has to portray a person 19 years older than herself!
As the Potter phenomenon grew, so did the number of famous faces clamouring for a part; Robbie Coltrane, Gary Oldman, Maggie Smith, Michael Gambon and Julie Walters just to name a few. However, amongst these stars, a few shone brighter than the rest; Alan Rickman as Professor Snape and Mathew Lewis as Neville Longbottom.  Throughout the franchise, Rickman has given superb performances, making the snide Professor Snape both fascinating and compelling. However, this installation showed a side of Snape many avid fans would not think possible! In one particular scene in which we get an insight into Snape's past, I was pretty sure there was not a dry eye in the house! Lewis' portrayal of bumbling boy Neville Longbottom added some light comedy to the dark tale. Amongst the battle scenes, Lewis' witty one lines break the ice during extremely tense moments. 
Another thing to be applauded about this film? The BAFTA award winning special effects. Since Warner Brothers announced the production was to be filmed in 3D, amy people thought it would ruin the tradition of the films. However, it did quite the opposite. The 3D effects "apperated" you from your seat into the heart of battle! From the dragons to the flying broomsticks, from the breathtaking interior of Gringotts to the majestic Hogwarts castle, the effects team managed to make the make-believe real! The audience were thrust into the heart of the scenes through the 3D effects, treating them to the thrills and spills of an emotional rollercoaster! 
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2 is an explosive ending to the most successful film franchise in history. This saga has shown British film industry at its best. Although it is the last instalment in the series, it is most certainly not the end. The Potter films will go down in cinema history. And, as Harry asked his father, "Will you stay with me?", his answer is quite true for ours. "Until the very end".
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is not only great but is better then all the other Harry potters.
