Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 is certainly a whopper of a finale. It strikes a completely different tone to the first part, but eases you in to this new feel with the opening sequence. It then spirals into the spectacular Battle Of Hogwarts. For me, this knocks spots off of the likes of the Battle for Minas-Tirith in Return of the King, despite the lesser scale of it. Why? Almost every single member of the titular hero's army is someone we know, someone named, someone who has been explored in the books at least, if not the films. Even those that don't, they're still people that the goodies have been to lessons with, or seen in the Ministry of Magic. That is why there is so much emotional resonance in this film, and that is what makes us care when these characters are being mown down in battle by curses and hexes and spells. Even when characters like Lavender, whom was one of the most annoying people in the franchise, die, you still feel sad to see them go. But in the end, whether through death or otherwise, every single one of those characters ends here. The poignant final scene, which harkens back to the first film so wonderfully, bookends this perfectly - After all, it ends where it all began.

The Epic Harry Potter comes to an end at last with Deathly Hallows Part 2. After such long series of movies one would think it invoked strong feelings but Harry Potter's last stand is just another mediocre blockbuster.

David Yates continues true to his directing style with Deathly Hallows 2 by mixing childish fantasy with dark settings and ominous CGI visuals. The mixture of these has never been my cup of tea and turns many scenes into something unreal and ridiculous. I mean, teenagers shooting beams of computer imaginary from wooden sticks at horrendous monsters is just not my idea of epic fantasy! And what is wrong with Mr. Potter; the worlds greatest wizards still looks stunned and is under performing when his annoying sidekicks pull meaningless spells and somehow manage to save the day.  

It is however not all bad (just most of it), the last Harry Potter manages to accomplish closure for the saga and for that it earns some points. For a very long time in Potter flicks there is now some occurrences in Deathly Hallows part 2 with clear consequences. The great evil is confronted and ultimately defeated. It took 8 movies but at last there is something concrete happening story wise. It does not fix the the whole series but Deathly Hallows Part 2 at least managed to keep me semi interested for the most part of the movie which can be accounted as credit for the movie.

I'm not a fan of the Harry Potter movies. A couple of them were OK but, for the most part, I find them boring and repetitive. The series finally concludes with Deathly Hollows Part 2 and, sadly, also finally achieves the dramatic strength which has been lacking for the last 7 1/2 movies. A little too late as a series to be sure but, at least the climactic flick isn't a chore to sit through like some of the others.The cast is fine, though the cast was never the problem for me, it was the scripts and direction that neutered most of them. But, as for this final chapter, let's not hand out any awards just yet. Hallows Part 2's script is still a bit muddled. I have seen all the Potter flicks and still have a hard time following what's going on (never read the books). And of course it contains dramatic strength, it's based on the second half of a climactic book so, it contains all the dramatic scenes and action. So in that sense it's kind of cheating. The FX during the numerous scenes of spectacle range from very good to cheesy. I was never enamored with the CGI in these films and this one is no different. There is a lot of action but, some of it reminds me of the confusing clutter that plagued the climax of Return of The Jedi. You really can't tell what's going on at times. The action only really flows when it focuses on intimate conflict between smaller groups of characters or the individual struggles with Harry and Voldemort. Another thing that's always annoyed me is that I'll never understand why the characters use their wands for some things but then struggle to accomplish other tasks on their own. It seems to me like a script contrivance to create drama. So, to a non-fan like me it is one of the better of the series, maybe the best but, when a series takes 7 1/2 movies to really get going, that's not something to wave your wand about.

Rowling, because without her, Harry Potter would be no where. Throughout this decade of amazing, high-rated movies, I couldn't have made a better ending to this epic series. They ended this epic series with an epic finale. Harry Potter, wherever you are, I'm right behind you, as are the millions and millions of other fans you had before me. You are amazing, as is J.K. Rowling, as is all your cast members, all your movies, and all your books.

Since my school managed to make the schedule implode I was able to watch the last entry in the series that was part of my chidhood. Was it worth it? Well I actually have to admit that this movie is pretty damn sweet and well worth the 130 minutes you'll have to spend with it. The story was probably the only problem with this movie, it has been quite a while since I last watched the final movies, so my memories of it were pretty vague and that made some of the plot twists very hard to follow.

Aside from that it is just as spectacular as you may expect from a triple-A movie. There are epic scenes with hundreds of actors firing special effects into the sky at the same time and the whole story is carried by top notch actors who spend ten years working themselves into this role. Since part 1 was nice enough to take up the entire first and second act, this movie is a well supported third act that never seems to end, it just jumps from one amazing moment to the other and most of the sideplots that started tying up got a tear lose in me. It should have been a long, epic thing but instead they just glossed over it.  Also, it was kind of weird when Voldemort dies.  He just poofs into ashes, I'm not even completely sure why, and he doesn't even say anything.

Harry Potter's 8th installment is the best in the series. With J.K. Rowling saying that she might be writing another Harry Potter book this movie could not be more hyped up. This is the best movie of the year!

This movie has action, adventure, suspense, drama, romance, and a touch of comedy (thank you, Ron Weasley). Let us not forget the awesome special effects. It also turns out to be a touching story of romance with a surprise you wouldn't even guess. The movie is not only for die hard Harry Potter fans who have read every book, it has something for everyone, young and old. There are some scary and sad parts so I would recommend the movie for age 8 and above, if you think your child could handle mild scariness. Most impressive to me was the heartwrenching performance of Alan Rickman (Professor Snape). This is Snape as you've never seen him before. Did I forget to mention the *magic*? The best part of all. I love when Professor McGonagal summons the Knights (or suits of armor) stationed around the castle and orders them to "Do your duty to our school!" Very cool to see. I would wager that the Harry Potter books and movies will be revisited by generations to come. This happens to be my favorite movie of all time and I'm 42 years old and extremely picky. My daughter and I started reading the books when she was 6. Finished them when she was 9. She has since read them all twice. She is 12 years old. Ultimately, the stories are of loyalty, friendship, heroism, and overcoming all odds to have good win out over evil. Highly recommend!

But great otherwise!

The final installment of the Harry Potter series couldn't have ended any better. This film is a huge contrast to it's predecessors. It's dark and fuses drama, love, and action seamlessly. The plot is well paced enough that by the end of the two hours, you can't believe it's over. Emma Watson, Daniel Radcliffe, and Rupert Grint have all transformed into the characters they play and I can't imagine anyone else taking their roles. I couldn't have hoped for a better ending to one of the greatest franchises of this century.

I've never been attached to the films surrounding Harry Potter and the magical realm of Hogwarts. The previous films were formulaic children's fantasy stories mixed with teenage love drama suited for high schoolers. While the latest films broke the mold some, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 was not only an excellent film, but may have elevated the series past mediocrity. For the first time in the series, the film carried some emotional weight and application that was absent in the previous films. Much like the adaptation of Return of the King, Part 2 finds a way to be a non-stop adventure film while also remaining the emotional core of the series. The scene where Harry, surrounded by his past loved ones, sacrifices himself for his friends is emotionally moving, and his resurrection and return to defeat Voldemort is a picture of the Gospel. The series has always boasted a cast of British finest actors and actress (which are too numerous to list here), but two performances specifically shine in the second part ; Ralph Fiennes' depiction of the arch villain Voldemort is a strong and elegant depiction of the Satan-like character, while the always reserved and sly "villain" Serous Snape (Alan Rickman) in a series of flashback scenes fills the gaps in Harry's story which not only allow Rickman to give a fleshed out performance that deserves him an Oscar nomination, but also shows how his character, since the first film, has been following a selfless ploy to help betray and defeat Voldemort. His sacrifice, as well as Harry's and the others, points not personal gain or a sense of greater good, but to follow a demand to do simply what is right. As Neville defiantly tells Voldemort, when all hope seems to be lost, that he and his friends will not die in vain. "But you will," he says, "because you're wrong." Perhaps the books are better and perhaps it isn't worth the 16-plus hours to get to this film. However, the final installment of Harry Potter does capture the importance of self-sacrifice and bravery in the face of reckless evil. For that, it is a magical experience.

An exhausted gasp - IÃ¢(TM)ve completed the arduous task of consuming the entire Harry Potter saga as movies. IÃ¢(TM)d say the 8 movies combined probably had the entertainment value of a single, pretty decent movie. Speaking as a MEGA Harry Potter fan, I am a litttle biased but I am not blind... my pure love for the books does not not allow me to be critical of the films. It was AMAZING. Literally, just over 2 hours of pure action, something which in other films can get annoying because there is no explanation but we have had 7 films of building up the tension beforehand. David Yates, in my opinion, managed to brilliantly weave in the heartfelt parts and there was no akwardness. As for the actors. FAN-BLOODY-TASTIC! How do I begin? Daniel, Emma, Rupert were amazing but I think the real stars here are Alan Rickman, Maggie Smith and Matt Lewis. Matt, usually a background character with Neville, was superb. He was perfect in portraying Neville and convincing us of his 'love' to Luna. Maggie Smith was amazing too. Miverna is one of my favourite characters especially in the Deathly Hallows and she really did her justice along with Julie Walters. As for Alan Rickman, if he is not nominated for an Oscar, then I officially declare the world blind. One of my favourtie parts of the book is Snapes memories, and when I found out before the film came out that Yates had tweaked it a bit I was furious, but really, it was for the better. I don't generally cry at film adaptations of books purely on the basis that no film can capture the essence of the book but I am not ashamed to say I cried like a baby. Overall, an amazing film, amazing acting, the special effects too, but above all... The. Best. Sendoff. Ever. A magnificent ending to the best franchise on Earth. Well done.

Being 14, you wouldn't think I could write a good review for a Harry Potter movie seeing as most 14 year old girls are hardcore twihards. I. Am. Not. A. Twilight. Fan. Let me make that perfectly frank. Back to the review!
Again, being 14, I grew up with Harry Potter. I saw the first movie when I was 4 and I was opened to the magical world and loved it. Growing up I thought the movies would never end......
Then they did.
And I couldn't have asked for a better send off.
Daniel, Rupert and Emma threw themselves into the role to make it the best portrayal of the main characters in all of the film series. Though, Harry and Ginny are of course undeniably awkward, Ron and Hermione had great on screen chemistry.
Did they miss out anything? Yes. They didn't explain the misconception of Dumbledore? No. But did they make the 'heaven' scene that confused the heck out of most of us the books a hell of a lot more understandable? Yes.
My personal favorite part of the movie, Snape's death. I was sobbing for the rest of the movie. It was beautifully played out and you honestly felt a strong bond with Snape's character for the first time in the history of the movie series.

All in all. A truly amazing movie.

Excellent and satisfying conclusion to the Harry Potter series. The series will always have a soft spot in my heart, even if it is small. The first Potter book was the first book I read from cover to cover when I was a young lad and I've seen every movie in the series with the exception of the 5th one. Every movie, at least of those that I've seen, has been good to excellent with the first two movies being the weakest. I felt that with the last three movies, the series really came into its own, as far as standing out on its own and not just relying on the fame of the name. Granted the name helped, but I think the last three movies being so good helped earn the movies some respect from people who may not have bothered otherwise. The storytelling improved, the acting improved, the visuals improved. Everything improved on a massive scale and that was really noticeable, at least to me, with these last three movies. So here with this last movie, we say goodbye to one of the most successful franchises in film history and boy does it go out with a bang. Unfortunately, the movie doesn't start out that way. It starts a bit slow and it feels like it was a left over from Deathly Hallows Part 1 tacked on at the beginning of this movie to make the movie longer. This is a minor complaint, because once the movie gets going, it really doesn't stop until its climax. As mentioned in my review for Deathly Hallows 1, I thought, when WB originally announced this splitting the last book into two movies, that it was mostly just greed on their part as the last book isn't even the longest book in the series. But having seen the first installment and seeing just how that movie built anticipation for this installment and how this movie paid it all off was nothing short of brilliant. I still think it was a matter of making more money, but you couldn't find a better way to end the series than with this movie. It just flowed perfectly. The movie was just excellent. The acting from the main cast (this being Daniel, Rupert, and Emma) has improved so much from the beginning and since they were never exchanged when they got older than they were supposed to be in the book, it felt like there was a real friendship between the two and I think this movie encapsulates that perfectly. In fact, the last scene at the Hogwarts castle...of Harry, Ron and Hermione holding hands and just standing there was the absolute perfect ending for the movie. I'd have much preferred this ending than to what they did *SPOILERS*, which is show them 19 years later, leaving their kids at the train station that takes them to Hogwarts. I get what they were trying to do, but it felt kind of hokey to me. The perfect ending was them holding hands at the castle and the movie ending. They were successful in destroying Voldemort but it was a very poignant moment and I think that would've, to me at least, made for a great ending. They were successful in defeating the villain but now what does their future hold...that kind of thing. Maybe it's just me, but I preferred that. Some of the scenes are also WAY too dark sometimes It's really very minor complaints in the big picture, when the movie is as dazzling and as satisfying in closing out a film series as I've ever seen. Trust me the complaints are minor, but again...I can't say enough good things about this movie. Very highly recommended.

Which brings me to this OTHER franchise whose last book is being split into two movies, Twilight. I haven't seen Breaking Dawn yet, I don't plan on going to theaters to watch it, but from what I've heard it's a pretty terrible movie, other than to the fans. This is exactly what I said in my Deathly Hallows 1 review, not every series can pull this off and I thought that Twilight doing this was just a recipe for disaster. The books are very poorly written, I've tried to read them...I can't. So you take this poorly written book and you make a movie out of it...fine, maybe you can use smoke and mirrors to distract from the real issues with writing. But you take the last book of a poorly written series and you decide you're going to split it up into two movies...that's going to expose EVERY weakness the series has tenfold and people are going to pick up on plot holes and mistakes quicker. That's just the nature of the beast. It shouldn't surprise anybody that it has been the worst reviewed of the bunch. Not to mention, at least the Potter series was building to this climactic battle between good and evil and the death of every character that died defending Harry has weight within the context of the series, it's not just ignored. Kids grew up with these characters and the characters matured along with them, so they have a REAL connection to these characters and what their outcome is. Can someone tell me what the point of Twilight is other than protecting one of the most unlikable people ever put to screen? If Bella was a real person, she'd be hated more than Kim Kardashian She's a shitty friend, she's shallow, she tried to trick Edward into having sex with her by promising that she'd marry him if he fucked her, she constantly plays Jacob and Edward against each other as she sees fit, she does absolutely nothing and people get killed for her and this has no consequences in the series. Why is she so important and why is she worth protecting? I don't know how in any way, shape, or form fans of the series can read all these books and say "Bella's a great character." There's nothing people can relate to, other if they want to have this Disney fantasy of having two guys fight over her in melodramatic stories. Everyone in the Twilight universe would be so much better off if she was dead. This could also be said about Harry Potter, but see that's the difference. In Potter they actually DEAL with this and how Harry reacts to every dying for him in this battle they really shouldn't have been in. And that's why, I think, the Twilight series will find it harder to appeal to anything other than teen girls and everyone else will just be dismissive of it. I'm not trying to weigh one series against the other, well I am...but I'm not. I'm just stating my reasons why I feel the Potter series will always be infinitely better than Twilight.

The end of the epic series comes to an end in what I felt was all too quickly. Having read the entire series beforehand, it is a common trend that basically, "Movies just don't live up to the books they are based on." I understand why this is the case though. Books can take pages and pages of space to give detailed and specific information, while movies generally don't surpass a 2-3 hour time limit ("The Matrix", "The Lord of the Rings", and "Harry Potter" may be movies that either max this limit or exceed it), so there are certain limitations to what can be covered in a book-turned-movie. 

This is not to say that this last installment of the Harry Potter series was boring or lacking in major ways. Overall, the film did a sufficient job of covering the ending of this series in a quick and "to-the-point" way.

As far as fantasy films go, Harry Potter's probably the best one, along with Lord of the Rings. Imitators like Eragon (boring book, even worse movie) haven't exactly lit the genre up, and like sci-fi, 99% of it is complete crap. 

Potter books and movies were some of my favorites as a kid, and I actually thought at one point that I'd be able to go to Hogwarts. Of course, I didn't, but now that it's all over, something feels missing. Potter was the last film series from the early 2000s to finish (the only other one before that was Shrek, and unlike the amazing first film, the sequels were crap). In our "post-modern" world of Glee and Jersey Shore and Twilight and Justin Bieber, there's really not a whole of of genuinely good entertainment anymore. 

Anyway, moving on to the film. This is the best of the Potters by far, although it is the complete opposite of the very bright and cheerful first film. Unlike the first Deathly Hallows (which was one of the worst ones, in my opinion), this one manages to combine action with story in a very thought-out way. I especially like how they dealt with Snape, a character who I always liked. In the end, Voldemort is disentegrated (he dies, tah dah), Ron and Hermione hook up (and she's looking more smoking hot than ever), and Harry saves the day. It's all a little bit depressing. Just wait for the inevitable reboot to see Potter again.

It's easy for the things that are grandest in scale to somehow seem unfulfilling when they conclude. I suppose the best thing I could say about the final part of Deathly Hallows is that it definitely was not unfuilfilling. But seeing as how I still haven't read the books, and I have not seen Order of the Phoenix or Half-Blood Prince, and jumped right in to these final films, I can't help but feel like something's missing. There's a reason for that, of course - it's because something is. But that's squarely on my shoulders. Point is, the Harry Potter films have a come a long way since Chris Columbus first brought the story to life on the screen. And it ends just about as well as it could end, despite preserving the book's infamously tacky fanfic throwaway coda. And to do so still...well, that's really saying something.

To this point the world of Harry Potter is well known to everyone around the world, even to those who have never read the books or seen the movies, even those that are tired of hearing about the series. To many it started with the great books by J.K. Rowling, and I was one of them. However, I did not start reading the books until the third one came out, previously siding on the fence of being sick of how popular it was. But when I picked those books for the first time I was hooked for over a decade. And then the movies began to come out and I was equally transfixed by the marvelous visual telling of this instant classic tale. Sadly, the series has to come to a close some time, and for the literature side it was a few years ago, though it remains to be seen if Rowling will continue the series in any way. For the films, that day came on July 15, but with such a remarkable series, it will live on forever.

This eighth and final film in the series is actually a continuation of the previous film, so we pick up our three young heroes, Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson), on the trail of finding the remaining horcruxes of Voldemort (Ralph Finnes). These horcruxes must be found and destroyed before the evil wizard can be brought down in the epic finale. The team encounters countless close calls on their way to the "Battle of Hogwarts" which concludes the series with the entire cast of characters coming together for one last time on screen.

Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of the film series has been its casting, which starts with the three main actors. They have grown so much over the series and it is great to have seen them mature right in front of our eyes. None of them perhaps truly shine in this installment, but they are so comfortable in their roles as Harry, Ron and Hermione at this point that you hardly notice that they are acting. At this point they truly are these characters. But past that is the astounding supporting cast which is cock full of English acting legends, and each actor, and in fact each character, is given their moment in this concluding chapter, which I found to be a very nice touch. Alan Rickman (Snape) and Ralph Finnes (Voldemort) are the standouts in this particular film, but enough cannot be said for what the entire veteran cast brought to the entire series.

 And Rickman is really important in this installment because Snape is such an important part of the story, which is adapted quite well once again by Steve Kloves. Much like the first part of The Deathly Hallows, the film appears to be pretty faithful to the book. Whatever changes or adjustments have, to this point, become almost background noise, for the filmmaking team under the direction of David Yates has become so great at creating the world of Harry Potter and making great films that whichever choices they seem to make, they always seem to be great choices, even when it differs from the source material.

The technical aspects, as always, are also astounding. The special effects, which have been somewhat of a calling card for the series, are top notch once again, taking full advantage of the many magical settings of the film as well as the epic battles and action scenes that are prevalent throughout the final chapter. The cinematography, which has become a common thread in the Yates directed films, is strong once again as director of photography Eduardo Serra captures the world in all its beauty, complete with interesting angles and framing choices. Alexandre Desplat, who has been one of Hollywood's hot composers of late, returns again for the score of this film and continues his hot streak, composing a blazing score for the film full of action, with the ability to be emotionally touching at the right points as well. And as the previous composers before him, his work is more subtle and complimentary than the great work of John Williams earlier in the series.

The film moves at a breakneck pace and really has little expository scenes, but this late in the series it almost feels like there shouldn't be. Because this is the latter half of the book, the entire film is pretty much 3rd act material, which means it is edge of your seat action from start to finish with little time to breath, but I cannot think of a better way to conclude the series. There is no way this is a stand alone film. Anyone that sees this film without seeing any of the others would be lost and would probably hate the film, but that simple fact almost makes this film that much better.

The previous films in the series have done such a great job of setting up and developing all these characters that this film not only gets away with being all 3rd act with little exposition, but it excels at it. For that reason I cannot imagine a better way to have ended the series. Everyone gets their due and their moment to shine. I would not call this the best of the series, though now that the series has concluded I am sure to resort to my style of ranking the books: why rank them, the entire series is great and magical. Harry Potter is a gift which was first given by J.K. Rowling, and since been regifted by Chris Columbus, Alfonso Cuaron, Mike Newell, and finally the wonderful David Yates. It will be ever present in the history of cinema as perhaps the most successful franchise both financially and artistically, but more importantly it will be in my personal collection for the rest of my life to enjoy and share with as many people as possible.

While it was a wonderful way to end the series, I was still disappointed by some of the plot changes.  Let me get the negatives out of the way.  I did NOT care for the final battle between Harry and Voldemort AT ALL; that was a terrible way to change the plot from the book. Also, the parts of the battle scenes that were a departure from the book seemed very contrived.  And I was very disappointed by the final scene in the train station.  They could have done so much more than that, but it was like they just threw it on the end of the movie only because they knew they had to.  David Yates treated it like a throwaway scene, and it showed.  As for the positives--the main characters are really at the end of their ropes by now, and Daniel, Rupert and Emma show those emotions brilliantly.  Daniel especially does well as Harry goes to meet what he thinks is his death.  The effects during the battle for Hogwarts are breathtaking and very believable.  All in all, very poignant, very magical, very believable (if you believe in magic, that it), and a very good end to a phenomenal series.

The film also shows how much the stars have grown as actors since they first walked through the doors of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, and they all do a fantastic job in the film, because they give us the feeling that they actually have been through all of these events in the series, and the film offers satisfying, yet not always happy, conclusions to all of the characters in the series. When I heard they were splitting the final book into two films I was quite curious to see how faithful they were going to be to the story. Part 1 slightly strayed away from the original story but I was still satisfied with the finished product. As a movie, Part 1 was good, and a great way to get the story going. As Part 2 approached, I waited with great anticipation. Cutting to the chase, I was completely blown away by this film. Again, while it doesn't retain everything in the final book, it pulls out the stops and remains a very close and faithful adaptation to my favourite book series. In fact, the film overcame some of the shortcomings that the final book suffered from. The final battle at Hogwarts seemed to be very rushed, and little description was given to how bad this war was. In the film, we truly witness the destruction of Hogwarts, and the powers that Lord Voldemort has mustered in his final attempt to kill Harry. Then there is the showdown between the Harry and the Dark Lord. In the book, I felt it was too short, failing to capitalize on the potential that an epic battle of this scale. As Dumbledore so accurately put it in the Half-Blood Prince, it would take considerable skill to defeat Voldemort even without his horcruxes. In the film, we truly witness Harry summoning all his magical skills to battle one-on-one with Voldemort, bringing the battle to a truly satisfying conclusion. All the actors did extremely well in this film, and seeing Neville Longbottom turn into a true badass was simply excellent to see. I'm sure going to miss this series but I know that they will live on forever. I recommend the books and films to everyone, you will truly be amazed.

This was the single most disappointing movie I've ever seen in my life.  Much of the drama and emotion that came through in the books is completely lost in this film.  Part of the blame lies with the young actors, who have never really had any other roles besides these and for the most part, had happy silly roles to portray, up until the last few movies.  This is where their acting goes south fast, Daniel Radcliff is absolutely horrible in this movie and shows no emotion at all.  The scene where he finds out that Fred, Remus, and Tonks are all dead should have been one of the most emotional scenes in the movie, yet it goes by as if nothing happened and is quickly forgotten.  The director, Yates, must also share some of this blame for not only getting his actors to act correctly but also for putting too much emphasis on special effects.  He did to this movie what George Lucas did to the Star Wars prequels, added flash and "excitement" through FX but lost all the connection with the characters.  Despite the entire movie being completely disappointing in itself, the worst was the final confrontation between Harry and Voldemort.  There was absolutely no feeling in it at all, just a lot of bright flashing lights, and Harry and Voldemort staring at each other.  The books had it completely different, actually realizing the effect of dialogue and its power.  Which brings me to another point, pointless and stupid deviation from the book.  One of the most powerful and shocking parts of this story is learning of Snape's true motives, and this movie completely butchers that.  I actually give credit to Yates here, fore making Alan Rickman seem like he has never acted before.  That takes true skill to make such a talented actor seem like an amateur.    All in all, I cannot believe I payed over $10 to see this atrocious movie, and if it were not for the Lord of the Rings trilogy, I would probably never have faith in book-to-movie adaptations again.

DO NOT get me going on this movie. I am a die-hard HP fan, so yes, it is hard for me to separate book from movie, but this movie was still garbage. Yes, there were good action scenes and yes, I cried (thanks to a stunning performance form Alan Rickman). This does not excuse so many problems with this movie. Oh, we just defeated Voldemort, but nobody act happy in the ending. How did Fred Weasley not get an on-screen death? How did anyone who hasn't read the books understand what the horcruxes were supposed to look like and the HUGE problem of finding them? There was no character development! The book had a made for movie ending, Harry and Voldemort circling each other with everyone watching in the great hall and Harry reveals how he defeated V. So what the heck was with that weird and dumb cliff-diving scene? Nobody else learns that Snape was a good guy and he was never redeemed. I understand that cuts need to be made for the big screen and I can forgive the exclusion of the Dumbledore/Aberforth back story and even leaving out the whole Percy drama...but this movie seriously was such a disappointment. I do NOT get the positive reviews. Part 1 was WAY better,

I gotta hand it to Potter, not because this is the last installment but because it tied everything from a decade together and captured the emotion from JK Rowling's books making this everything a Harry Potter movie should be. Picking up right where Part 1 concluded, Part 2 is not afraid to dive right into the action and literally take off (on a damn dragon mind you!). While the majority of the film is 'the battle of Hogwarts' this does more than provide the incredible special effect-filled spectacular battle between wizards good and evil, but it captures the true core of the emotion from its central, beloved characters we've followed (in the film world) since 2001. From the deaths of the tragic characters to the justification of self sacrifice and triumphing over evil (I don't care how tacky it sounds), this franchise comes to a near perfect bitter sweet close for Potter and pals. Now that Part 2 is finished, this final film can be judged the way it was meant to be... two different, incredibly unique parts that make up one enormous heart-felt story. Though a controversial split, it would have been a disgrace to give Harry anything but the send off he deserves and while yes, this movie receives the "best movie of the Summer" award, partially as a crutch due to my long affection for Potter, I can say that this final Potter installment (both Parts 1 and 2) is far and away the most well done Potter film, as a faithful adaptation to the book and as a phenomenal film in general. Once the movie ends there's a sad yet necessary completion to the franchise. Suddenly those missing pieces are filled in and a 10 year weight is lifted off its audiences shoulders allowing every previous Potter installment to play its individual part in this building block of one of the greatest franchises of our generation. Looking back, one can appreciate all the different directors who developed each installment to their own perfection allowing every film to feel different than the last but ultimately each a bridge to the next. And with David Yates successfully developing these last 4 chapters (3 if you count Hallows as one movie), not one Potter film can be without the other and you can truly take in all the compassion for this series when these final credits roll for one last time. Its been a good run; one hell of a ride, but dammit, well done Harry. Well done.

96%/(8.4 out of 10) is a bit high. It suggests that this movie is as good as any of the LOTR films. And it isn't; it doesn't reach the heights of any of them. I think the critics took a slightly inflated liking to this just because it was very good PLUS the last movie of the series. Add to that the fact that I actually really enjoyed 7.1 and still not sure why the critics were relatively unkind to that one. The quality between the two are about the same to me.

Anyway, with those caveats out of the way, it certainly was a well-crafted, very enjoyable fantasy-adventure film. I haven't read the book yet, so I'm judging it on purely filmic terms. The young cast has visibly grown in skill as much as in physical stature. The performances here are superb by all involved. In fact, I wasn't much of a fan of Radcliffe's Potter through the first, say, 5 movies, so his improvement has been especially notable. Also, a particular sequence involving Snape is the first time a Potter film brought tears to my eyes. Of course, that's because I wasn't expecting the revelation since I haven't read the series. To diehard fans it may not quite move them. I also very much disliked the epilogue; it seemed a little TOO happy and the makeup work wasn't even well-done. Still, very good escapist entertainment. Watching the movies has now induced me to read the books, by the way. So a job well done for that too.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows part 2 lives up to its expectations as the finale. It is also literally so dark that I had to adjust the brightness on my TV screen.

The story plays it safe and goes for the grand confrontation involving armies on both sides. The battleground is the Hogwarts campus. The evil forces outnumber the good. The siege involves destruction, mayhem, and lots of motivation that no longer need explanation by this chapter. Supporting characters reveal new sides of themselves. And Harry finally confronts Voldemort, wand to wand.

It's a sensational film of computer effects used to depict the intensity of structures being demolished, and powerful spells being conjured. We see the main trio running away from engulfing flames, falling rubble, and they eventually ride on big broomsticks together, as all wizards should be imagined. 

I enjoyed the brief revisit to Gringotts bank. It's interesting how the passageways to the vaults were never fully developed and instead look more like mining tunnels. And what resides deep below is quite a surprise.

After seven successful Harry Potter movies, viewing satisfaction of the eight part can grow into weariness. But the fact remains that they are stories of a fantastic imagination.

Epic. A perfect way for the Harry Potter series to end. Special effects were amazing. The acting was incredible. Having grown up with these characters and seeing it all end truly is heartbreaking but they do it justice with PART 2. Ive said this many times. A book is a book and a movie is a movie. As much as we would love every word to come to life in the movie there is no possible way every single page can make it into the movie. I think the writers and the director do an amazing job in keeping Harry's point of view throughout the movies and using select parts from the book as well as creating their own for the movies make it that much better.

It's a pretentiously over-rated blockbuster that takes every aspect of the series before it and defiles it for the sake of box office bucks.  It's hard to think a movie in this series could be any worse than the Order of the Phoenix, but this movie takes the cake. It took every deep plot twist and every emotional aspect of the movie and completely downplayed it to have big computer-generated fight scenes as the main driving point. The sincerity is underwhelming and you're investment in these characters is completely dismantled when every character besides Harry and Voldemort are shoved into the corner and away from the story into the realm of minor characters. The movie is riddled with plot holes and questions left unanswered because it assumes that the audience is too overwhelmed in emotion to notice them. This is a terribly rendered and watered-down version of the book that audiences and critics should be up in arms against and brutally tearing apart, but instead I see people too caught up in the ending of something so uniquely nostalgic to them that they don't even bat an eye at all the flaws.

If youre a fan of the books you will love 3/4 of the movie. The last 1/4 will make you wish you never read the books. There is a single scene that sets the tone for the rest of the movie and absolutely ruins it. I loved part 1 and thought it was finally a potter movie that was "almost" Oscar worthy. It had such drama and captured the essence of the book. I had huge hopes for part 2. They were ruined in an instant.  I don't even understand how Rowling allowed some scenes to occur in the movie. 
Looking at this from the outside I can see why this movie is popular. It has a lot more action than the book. But disappoints in certain areas that could make the main character really stand out. He seems like the same confused boy he started out to be in the first movie. There is no closure, but that matches the book perfectly. It's worth the watch and you kind have to if you haven't read the books. But do yourself a favor and read them.

Many superlatives will try and fail to describe the gratifying nature of this final chapter in the cinematic Harry Potter experience. Avoiding all attempts at originality, I will simply call it "Highly Recommended" for all fans of the book and movie franchise. I doubt such a ambitious series of films could have anticipated as pleasing a conclusion as this one. With plenty of action and more than a handful of poignant emotional moments, the conclusion of this epic series is appropriately incredible.

A piece of my childhood concluded when I closed the lid on the final book, but the films helped rekindle a bit of the Potter fever, and as an adaptation it is sometimes more than that.
Deathly Hallows- Part 2 is one part bittersweet, and three parts thrill ride. There are some missteps along the way, but the entire franchise was consistent and well made. This was a series treated with love and care, and I hope the fans treat the film the same way. We lucked out with these films, Potter fans.
But to review this particular film, there's not much to be said. Deathly Hollows shows Potter at his most mature. The tone of the film is suitably heavy handed and dark, reflecting the woes of becoming a young adult. I was reminded in a lot of ways by Link emerging from the Temple of time, being brought into a dark and threatening world, a stark contrast to the whimsy of childhood.
This is a franchise that is must see viewing for the younger crowd, but entertaining and mindful, with plenty of underlying, adult oriented content. Watch this, then watch it with your kids, and try to get them to read the books. From start to finish, Harry Potter's simply magic.

I've never been attached to the films surrounding Harry Potter and the magical realm of Hogwarts. The previous films were formulaic children's fantasy stories mixed with teenage love drama suited for high schoolers. While the latest films broke the mold some, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 was not only an excellent film, but may have elevated the series past mediocrity. For the first time in the series, the film carried some emotional weight and application that was absent in the previous films. Much like the adaptation of Return of the King, Part 2 finds a way to be a non-stop adventure film while also remaining the emotional core of the series. The scene where Harry, surrounded by his past loved ones, sacrifices himself for his friends is emotionally moving, and his resurrection and return to defeat Voldemort is a picture of the Gospel. The series has always boasted a cast of British finest actors and actress (which are too numerous to list here), but two performances specifically shine in the second part ; Ralph Fiennes' depiction of the arch villain Voldemort is a strong and elegant depiction of the Satan-like character, while the always reserved and sly "villain" Serous Snape (Alan Rickman) in a series of flashback scenes fills the gaps in Harry's story which not only allow Rickman to give a fleshed out performance that deserves him an Oscar nomination, but also shows how his character, since the first film, has been following a selfless ploy to help betray and defeat Voldemort. His sacrifice, as well as Harry's and the others, points not personal gain or a sense of greater good, but to follow a demand to do simply what is right. As Neville defiantly tells Voldemort, when all hope seems to be lost, that he and his friends will not die in vain. "But you will," he says, "because you're wrong." Perhaps the books are better and perhaps it isn't worth the 16-plus hours to get to this film. However, the final installment of Harry Potter does capture the importance of self-sacrifice and bravery in the face of reckless evil. For that, it is a magical experience.

Wow. Just wow. It truly did all end here. After 10 years and 8 movies, the epic saga of the boy who lived came to an end. And for anyone, fan or not, it did not disappoint. The bombastic qualities of the Battle juxtaposed with the somber emotion of the revelation of Snape's true identity was... amazing. It skipped no beats, and did great justice to it's source material. I was very literally in tears for the last 30 minutes or more of the movie, from The Pensieve scene, to the epilogue. Maybe it was because the movie was genuinely sad, maybe because it was the last movie in the series, or maybe both, this was one of the most somber movies I have ever seen. It was truly an emotional epic. The epilogue scene, although loathed by many, was terribly tragic. It wasn't meant to be sad, but seeing the Hogwarts Express leaving, with John Williams' theme motif in the background was truly saddening. Why does it all have to end? Why does my childhood have to die. Why can't these characters and this place that we have come to love have to leave us. But, I digress. All other aspects of the movie are amazing. From the acting, highlighted by Alan Rickman, to the score, that fits the movie ever so greatly, I loved it. But, we must always remember that "Hogwarts will always be open to to welcome you home". We must remember that the books and the movies shall always live on. As long as there are those of us that love this world, it shall never truly die. Goodbye Harry, you shall always be missed.

The final installment of the grand Harry Potter series is filled with drama, thrills, action, excitement, and just the right amount of finality. Director David Yates reigns in a wildly-popular franchise and creates a very solid and fitting finale. Though this installment is the shortest out of the series, it does not mean it is lacking anything. The character arcs are all fleshed out and finished nicely. And all the supporting elements, from the screenplay, to the sets, costumes, film editing, visual effects, and music, all cohesively come together nicely. However, since this is Part 2, you really need to see Part 1 in order to understand what is going on in this installment. And the material left in this section of the original novel really isn't enough to help the audience if they haven't seen or read any of the other movies. You really need to watch the first installment to at least get the gist of what is going on here. And though there was not a lot of plot left to flesh out, I still felt that Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves could have taken a few liberties and strengthened the script further. They had all the time in the world to make the film even more solid, from adding some more dialogue for some characters to reworking some of the story's exposition. Though it was miles better than Part 1, they could have strengthened the weaker parts, such as the final duel between Harry and Voldemort. It is such an important and iconic scene in the novel, and since this is the last film, it should be just as important, gripping, and iconic. But it really wasn't. It was quite anti-climactic. But despite the script problems, hands down, the most impressive aspect of this film is the battle at Hogwarts. The action is so impressive, thrilling, and mesmerizing. It is truly a visual feast. And Alexandre Desplat's score for this last half of the film is right up there with John Williams' work on the first three Harry Potter films. And Desplat's nod to Williams during the epilogue was the icing on the cake. Despite the epilogue's awkward feeling, Desplat rescues the scene by saluting Williams' work from the first film and finishing this film and the entire series with the beautiful swells of Williams' phenomenal music. Overall, this was a very solid installment and a pretty satisfying conclusion to an incredible series.

Overall this film is great, one of the best films I've seen this year. The acting is spot on, jokes are handled well, and the visuals and battles are handle extremely well. I have no doubt that this film will get an Oscar nom for Best Picture. I give "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2" a 4.5/5, an amazing end to an amazing franchise.

HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS: PART 2 (2011)

Though the main focus is the massive final battle, it felt as though it was lacking structure throughout the battle itself.  Everything leading up to the battle was great, and the last like 3 minutes before the credits roll was also VERY well done and extremely emotional for fans.  But the battle itself was a MESS!

Every time the story was starting to move well, it transitions to something that was really cool in the book, but out of place and confusing at times because of quick editing and a lack of setup beforehand.  As a result, many of the primary villains, besides Voldemort, would appear when convenient and got lost in translation.

All the big and dramatic scenes had the opposite problem; Literally every scene of importance was announced with and overuse of slow-motion and a barrage of soundtrack that was more loud than poetic. It happens so often that by the time Harry and V lock spells for the fifth time, you are desensitized to it.  

Also, I understand that this is a dark chapter in the HP story-line, however that doesn't mean the entire film needs to be literally dark.  Low filters, lack of lighting and a lack of color really lose their artistic edge after the first hour. There is still a sun in the Wizarding World...as far as I know...

This is not a bad movie, its just not a great movie, especially compared to the other films in the series.  Its hard to tell whether the film makers truly wanted to appease the fans, or just make it look good to critics. It was more style than it was substance, hence the fans' many complaints.  As a slightly-above-average HP fan (Read all of the books at least twice...Yea...), I expected more than what I got.

Without a doubt, one of the most anticipated films of the year, if not ever, but easily manages to succeed in the daunting task of living up to a whole generation's expectations.
    Picking up moments after the last film left off, Part 2 launches in to the action, with many impressive and extremely well filmed action sequences, including the escape by dragon-back from Gringott's and the Death Eaters' siege on Hogwarts.
   However, be it for good or bad, this film is unashamedly for Potter fans, glancing off plot details, assuming the audience understands and leaving those disinterested in the series without a chance. 
   Stunningly shot, the film is thrilling to the final frame, and will easily keep audinces on the edge of their seats. This coupled with heart-wrenching goodbyes to some of the most loved characters in a decade, played by some of the best British actors in the business, the film undoubtedly packs a major punch.
    All in all, Hallows Part 2 is a fitting end to the highest grossing film franchise ever, and is by far the best in the series.

Great ending to a great long series

This film was a good ending to the mammoth series it was but it wasn't a great ending. Why only 2 hours and 10 minutes? I mean, this is it. This is going to be the final hurrah and you can't go longer, more in depth with scenes and battles? What gives? One scene in particular bothered me: the Snape-from-the-past scene. It felt rushed and ti certainly did not contain all the elements that the book offered up as storyline. This scene should have been slowed down and should have included everything the book had. This was supposed to be Alan Rickman's big moment in the whole series and they flashed through it as if it was a minor subplot with minimal effect on the story. Frustrating. 
Now, that being said, it was a very enjoyable film and certainly a nice sendoff for the whole cast of characters that everyone grew to love over the years. The battle scenes (should have been longer but I digress) were incredible with amazing special effect and I loved the end battle with Harry and Voldemort. Excellent work. This definitely is a must-see for every Potter fan and a repeat watching for every Potter fan. Just don't be surprised when the film ends and you are wishing there were more.

One of the better movies in the Harry Potter franchise, which isn't saying overly much, but it's a pretty good movie nonetheless. It's weakest points are the same ones that have plagued the franchise since day one: weak character development, over-dramatization and major plot holes that are derived from the original books themselves. Plus yes, I happen to like Hermione (Emma Watson) as a character, but was it still necessary to make her such a Mary Sue in these movies? Feels kind of ridiculous when the female sidekick is a thousand times more competent than the hero. But, as I said, this is good movie. It manages to overcome its weaknesses remarkably well, feeling intense and satisfying and delivering a rather good ending. It's not perfect by any means, but I can live with it. Good end to the series.

As a true Potter fan I really did expect more from the final film installment. I've watched the films from the very beginning, and although they've never lived up to the high standards of the books they have really begun to disappoint me since David Yates took over as director. This was no exception. Technically it was amazing, the special effects were astounding. The acting level was generally high too, and the final battle was exciting and fast paced. However, so much of hte emotion and depth was missing from the film. Harry's final goodbye with Ron and Hermione before he thinks he is going to die is under acted and not nearly tear jerking enough for three best friends. Ginny, once again, is a terrible character. She is wimpy and not the feisty character that I fell in love with. There is no chemistry with her and Daniel Radcliffe. At all. The deaths are done appallingly, You don't even see Fred's death, and you only know Lupin and Tonks are dead from seeing thier corpses for less then ten seconds. Which is horrible and ridiculous. Ron, Hermione and Harry's discussion at then end is also slightly jerky and awkward. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't awful, I've already mentioned some of it's positives, and it's the best film under David Yates' direction. But as a whole, by this stage in the series, the charm and affection seems to have been drained from the films, and it's a great shame...and annoyance!

The Harry Potter franchise is arguably the most successful franchises in history. As a member of a generation that fell in love with J.K. Rowling's fantasy epic, I was extremely satasfied with the final movie of the series, and Harry Potter's final send-off for a generation. Harry Potter made my generation fall in love with reading, and could make even the dimmest of  readers fall in love with literature. The previous seven films had their merits, but The Deathly Hallows Part 2 is the crown jewel of the Harry Potter film crown. For over 10 years we have been enthralled by the lives of three young wizards as they have undertaken perilous journeys, battling unimaginable foes against incredible odds, all while being confronted by the challenges of simply growing up. "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2" (2011) is the perfect Harry Potter movie, that soundly finishes off this epic series of films on a triumphant note.

I have already gone on record saying how much I loved "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1" (2010), and yet, believe it or not, Deathly Hallows Part 2 is even better. While Part 1 acts like a place holder, Part 2 takes everything we have learned and experienced with the last 7 movies and masterfully crafts the perfect finale to one of the most amazing tales in movie history. Returning director David Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves takes the best that the final book has to offer, and create a stark contrast between the two parts. While the first part was dark, brooding and desolate and a story of resistance fighters of circumstance living off the land, part 2 is nearly all action and is the climax of the entire series, with the fate of Harry and everyone and everything holding on by a mere thread.

As with all the other films, Deathly Hallows Part 2 contains a great degree of psychological depth, though it is very much at the forefront in this installment. Early on in the series, the white and black hats where easy to see, and proper action was always taken in regards to the latter. However, as the series progressed, black and white turned to shades of grey, and determining who to trust or who was on who's side became quite the challenge. Well with the final part of the puzzle coming to fruition in this film, a great moral comes with it. One that shows us that many of the seemingly easy judgments we made earlier on in the series were far off the mark, and that this wonderful world has many more facets than we might have thought.

Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, and Rupert Grint, originally unknowns when cast for "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" (2001) a decade ago, have grown up before our eyes to become very competent actors. Daniel Radcliffe, as the titular Harry Potter, has been the standard bearer throughout all 8 films, and in this final installment, with the fate of the world hanging in the balance, he rises to the occasion like never before, flexing his well developed thespian muscles. His strengths have always laid in being able to convincingly portray the pain and anguish his character has felt throughout the series, a task that requires that special something to induce empathy, and once again, along with his constant companions Hermione Granger, played by the beautiful Emma Watson, and Ron Weasley, played by Rupert Grint, perfectly elucidate the vast material at play in this film.

A well deserved Best Supporting Actor Academy Award Nomination should finally go to Alan Rickman who has masterfully starred as Severus Snape throughout all 8 films. His deadpan, humorless, droll portrayal of the conniving and condescending menace of a man has been a highlight of the franchise, and one can only hope that the Academy finally recognizes the brilliance he has brought to this series. Another stand out in the series has been the dictatorial and ruthlessly evil, Lord Voldemort, played frighteningly by Ralph Fiennes. His tone is this film is far from the omniscient, all powerful, murderous master of the dark arts we have grown to know throughout the series. He is desperate, agitated, neurotic, and distrustful of those even closest to him...easily paralleling Hitler's fall towards the end of the WWII, though I suspect that will be missed by the young fans out there. Maggie Smith, as Professor Minerva McGonagall, also deserves a special mention, as she steps up big time to make for the loss of Headmaster Albus Dumbledore, and finally getting to see her cut loose in battle is a very welcome sight. Matthew Lewis as the much loved Neville Longbottom, also deserves a mention as he finally completes his transition from dimwit to hero.

Along with the fantastic main cast, this movie also does a nice job of including many past characters from the "Harry Potter" universe, though due to Deathly Hallows Part 2 being the shortest film in the franchise, its a shame they didn't make it longer, and didn't give those beloved characters more than just a cameo. Same goes with many of the locations and peculiarities at play in the film. A longer run time would have given those characters a proper and worthy send off and revisiting those old locations would have been a nice tickle of nostalgia.

One of the consistant stand outs of this franchise has always been the magic, creatures, and far out imagination at play. The CGI and special effects has always been top notch, and this film lives up to that once again. However, as with all the other films in the series, this is once again a movie about friendship, and is grounded in its heart and soul, that just happens to have amazing special effects that join up for the ride. Many movies today should take note of this, as over the top special effects alone do not make a good film, but its the loveable characters and experiences they undergo that make us care. Also, I feel I should note that I don't believe this movie needs to be seen with the darkening affects of the 3D gimmick, as the past movies have been amazing in simply good old 2D, so don't fall for that Warner Bros. cash cow.

I will be honest, I am by no means a "Potterhead", and have not even read any of the books, and therefore am sure to have missed many of the special easter eggs and nuances that only hardcore Rowling readers will catch. However, I have thoroughly enjoyed every one of the movies in this series, that have been compared to "The Wizard of Oz" of its time, and have very much loved these characters that I have grown up watching. This final movie is a very bit sweet moment, as it closes a part of my childhood, but has been very worth the ride. I highly doubt we will ever see a decade long series such as this one that has been produced with as much love and integrity, and has continued to dazzle us the entire way through.

"Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2" is a fantastical film that perfectly wraps up one of the most important franchises in movie history. From the once again stunning special effects, to the beloved characters trapped in the maelstrom of world ending fate, this movie has something for everyone. The story finally comes full circle like any good myth should, and is the perfect franchise capper. If you have every escaped into this world, even but for a moment, you owe it to yourself, and the characters within it, to see this movie. A well deserved A+!

In this summer's "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2", Daniel Radcliffe and Co. pleasantly come into their own, completing an iconic and mystifying ten year movie run.
	As an avid reader of the books, who had his nit-picky issues with the previous seven films, I was admittedly cautious walking into the packed South Dennis cinema for a midnight showing of Harry Potter's self-promoted "epic conclusion". Fanboys and girls all around, some in full Hogwarts garb, eagerly shuffled into the theater, visibly excited for the event.
	After a slight issue in the projection room, which led to a full theater viewing of the "Captain America" trailer almost five times, the trailers began working and everyone in the room fell into an excited silence.
	My thoughts contemplated over the next few minutes the fact that even if the movie wasn't enjoyable, at least I got to see the first teaser trailer for 2012's "The Dark Knight Rises".
	In short, "Hallows Part 2" delivered in its promise of grandeur. Unlike the slow-paced "Hallows Part 1", nearly half the movie is an action scene, beautifully choreographed with special effects impressively crafted to create a mixed feeling of chaos, excitement, and magic.
	The story continues where it left off, with the evil Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) stealing the famed elder wand from the grave of Albus Dumbledore (Michael Gambon). Immediately it moves onto Harry (Radcliffe), Ron Weasley (Rupert Grint), and Hermione Granger (Emma Watson) continuing their search for Voldemort's horcruxes: dark magical items containing a piece of Voldemort's soul.
	An impressively sequenced heist of Gringotts Bank, flows swiftly into the final battle at Hogwarts School, and eventually a final confrontation between Harry Potter and Lord Voldemort.
	These actors have truly come into their own. After being tossed into a series that would encompass their teenage years, Radcliffe, Watson, and Grint seem to have truly grown into their acting abilities, bringing the lovable characters from the books to expertly executed fruition. Their performances allow us to see their growth since The Sorcerer's Stone in 2001.
	The acting in the film is superb. Call me crazy, but I'm ready to submit Alan Rickman as Severus Snape up for a Best Supporting Actor Oscar. The story truly is able to find itself in its conclusion, touching on themes of friendship, loyalty, family, and of course, the power of good over evil.
	Another important quality is its likeness to the book which is something I haven't seen done well since the third Harry Potter film, "Prisoner of Azkaban". "Hallows Part 2" takes all necessary precautions to make sure every enjoyable and necessary scene from the book is present. Inclusion of the Fiendfyre chase sequence and the conversation with the eerie Grey Lady add to the suspense resonating in each of the characters, which in turn makes its way into the audience.
	Most importantly, it left the audience wishing for a magical intervention that would make the experience never end. But as was said in "Chamber of Secrets", "he'll never be gone, not as long as those who remain are loyal to him". Something tells me, looking over the sea of Potter fans, that he'll be around for a while.

I have some very mixed feelings towards the final Harry Potter movie. On one hand it was epic and emotional and on the other hand I was really frustrated. Lets start with the bad. The movie was waaaay to rushed. The final movies comes in just barely over 2 hours, easily making the final installment the shortest of all the movies. This short running time time leads to much to short duels and battles and it skims over almost every major death in the movie. The whole reason they split Deathly Hallows was so that they could fit everything from the books into the movie. So why then does it feel like Part 2 was rushed? I sincerely hope that this movie gets an extended cut Blu-Ray because it desperately needs one.

Now onto the good stuff. This movie will bring you close to tears, which is exactly what should happen when watching the final movie in a truly epic saga. The whole time your sitting there on the edge of your seat wondering how it's all gonna end. Even if you read the books and know the ending, you're heart will still be racing. The special effects looked stunning as always and the performances were the best yet. I'd go on and on about the good stuff but I think it's be best if you just watched it yourself.

All in all I liked the movie, but it was kinda disappointing. It didn't have everything that this ending needed to make it perfect. Still highly recommended though.

This movie picks up where the last one left off, with Harry, Ron, Hermione and Luna narrowly having escaped sure death at the Malfoy's. The main trio resume their search for the horcruxes, using the goblin they rescued, Griphook, to hatch a plan to enter Bellatrix Lestrange's vault at Gringott's Wizard Bank and nab the horcrux they are sure is hidden away down there. Once managing that feat they figure there is just one horcrux left, and that it is hidden somewhere within Hogwarts. The only problem is that Snape is now headmaster, there are Death Eaters and Dementors all over the place! Nevertheless the gang hatch a plan to enter the school, with help from Dumbledore's brother, Aberforth, and the hunt is on. Harry's presence in the school eventually becomes noticed by Snape however, which means that soon Voldemort and all of his cronies are knocking at the door. What ensues is an epic battle in and around the castle, and a fight to the finish between He Who Must Not Be Named and the Boy Who Lived. This was a really good film and a fantastic conclusion to one of the best franchises around! Unlike the first Deathly Hallows movie this one was pretty much non-stop action, and with all of the deaths of important main characters you could hear a pin drop in the theatre I watched it in. It was so exciting to see this film but also kind of sad as well, it is the end of something so amazing that's been ongoing in our lives for a long time. Can't wait for the DVD, then I can watch all of 'em in a row!

Being split into multiple installments certainly improved "The Deathly Hallows" as a film adaptation of complex source material but it still can't shake the typical follies of the series. Much like George Lucas did with his prequel films, DH Pt. 2 abandons the richness and emotion of the characters and remarkable drama of the story arc for a flurry of special effects and action sequences. The brilliant dynamic between Harry and his doppleganger Voldemort is dumbed down and flattened to appeal to the largest possible audience, the final battle at Hogwarts being a thin, lifeless and easy to swallow Wild West style showdown for the lowest common denominator of action fan. Looking back on the completed series as a whole, the Potter films have matured in visual aesthetic only. The magic is, and always was, in the books. These films may be entertaining but they are nothing more than spectacle; they posess no lasting artistic value.

The end of an era...again.
Seeing the series involve as something for kids into a multi-million dollar franchise is a strange thing.  Not many people have experienced this since Star Wars finished.
Now, seeing Harry Potter continue his quest to kill Voldemort is almost a coming-of-age event.
The first third of the film was a slow brewing leading to the climatic fight at Hogwarts.  Kudos to the special effects who obviously wanted to visualise the spectacular wizardry duels and all the actors convey the bravery and determination of their characters.  Certain plotholes and book-to-film differences change the mood of the film so the consistency is slightly uneven at places but to see everything on celluloid is worth overlooking all those little niggles.
This closes the series with a satisfying conclusion and Harry Potter fans will be safe in the knowledge that Potter film marathons will have a worthwhile ending.

of story from this one.

Very, very good, all the way through. The final Harry Potter is a fitting, grown-up (mostly) end to a series about children who grew up as we watched. Most of that is due to the careful and wise planning of J.K. Rowling in writing the books, of course. But all of the principal characters who began way back in "Sorceror's Stone" hold up their end as well. No, this wasn't "Lawrence of Arabia," but then, it wasn't supposed to be. Like the films before it in the series, this one tells the story it set out to tell masterfully - even, yes, magically.

The first book was released not long after my seventh birthday, and the eighth movie came out soon after my twenty-first. "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2" was certainly a fitting conclusion to millions of childhoods - moody and action-packed with almost enough Maggie Smith to be satisfying - but Rowling's epilogue didn't translate well to the big screen, and major inconsistencies with conclusive parts of the source material brought the overall quality down. Check out my full review of summer 2011's hits and misses at confessionsofafilmaholic.wordpress.com.

Most generations have certain pieces of pop culture that define them. Beatlemania and rock n' roll, Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, Nirvana. For my generation, for better or worse, I believe that defining factor is Harry Potter. Well, it's either that, Twilight or Britney Spears, and I really hope it's Potter.

Either way, this is a big deal, the books are among my favourites, and I felt the franchise had been on a steady decline since the incredible adaptation of "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban". But Deathly Hallows II represents a timely return to form. The acting is as good as it can be when the lead character is played by Daniel Radcliffe, and it's a visually stunning action fest to remedy the well... boring Part I.

Definitely better that I was expecting.

The special effects are brilliant, and the story unfolds at a brilliant pace as the film - and series - races toward its surprisingly unsatisfying conclusion. That its unsatisfying can only be blamed on Yates, who keeps his world dark and dreary right up until the end. The good acting of Part I has disappeared and returns to its usual ho-hum quality. The three lead actors are overshadowed by the special effects and characters from the first six films appear sporadically throughout. I believe this is to create nostalgia now that the series is coming to a conclusion but it just makes the screen look muddled with too many people gathered together in an attempt to defeat a villain whom I had at this point stopped caring about. Overall, it's a good ending and that's the problem with it. It's just...good.

That said, even as I watched other people cry around me, the most excited I got through the whole film was at Neville's sudden turn at leading man; and even that wasn't terribly thrilling. When I think of the first two potters, I get so many memories, of both the film and of my childhood. I think of moments of love, evil, fear, laughter, and magic. Both in the sense of the wave of a wand and in the sense of the magic of movies themselves. I then think of 3-4. I get all the same feelings as before with one addition, the feeling of epicness. This was the golden age of potter for me. I was more into the books then ever, and the films were at their highest level. More importantly, my knowledge of cinema was expanding. I was now watching lord of the rings, Indiana jones, and star wars. I had stepped into a much larger world. Then came 5-6. These are to be honest among my least favorites. The flaws were more apparent know, as the films didn't have the same childhood connection as before. Still, I find myself thinking about some moments from them with a nostalgic sense from time to time. There was also a feeling with these two, especially with the last book being realesed, that it was coming to an end. Not just the franchise, but my childhood it self...

I wasn't a big fan of part 1. I realize it was all set up for the big finale, but I still think it could have been better. This, on the other hand, is satisfying. Not a masterpiece, not ground breaking, but satisfying. I can't really give this a normal review. Like all the previous films, I don't see this film as performances and plot points, but as a collection of moments. The feeling of freedom when a dragon escapes. The feeling of sadness when we see snape's story come full circle. The feeling of awe as we see a character comes to terms with his own death. The feeling of pure joy when we see a charachter rise up and prove themselves to be more then just comic relief. Then, the final fight between Harry potter and lord Voldemort. The event that 10 years of films have been leading up to. The pay off to our childhoods. But, that's not the moment sticks out for me. The moment that sticks out for me Is the final scene. We see Harry, now grown up, sending his child off to hogwarts. We then see Harry again, one last time. We hear that music, that defines childhood and magic for me. And the credits roll. Could they have ended it any better? So, my childhood is finished. I leave it behind, at the movies. Where I hope to find it again next time I come. Is this movie flawed? Yes. But why would I feel the need to point these flaws out?

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 is the best installment in the Harry Potter franchise and is an magical conclusion as well
Harry, Ron and Hermione continue their quest to destroy Voldemort's Horucruxes after destroying one of them, all the while Voldemort becomes stronger and they discover the significance of the three Deathly Hallows. When the trio discover a Horucrux inside Hogwarts they decide to go back, but Voldermort has control of the school with Professor Snape (Alan Rickman) as the new headmaster and Dementors gaurding the grounds and are looking for Harry. 
But You Know Who now has the yet unbeatable Elder Wand, he aims to complete his final stage to ultimate power and launches an attack on Hogwarts School, where the trio return for one last stand against the dark forces that threaten to take over the Wizarding and Muggle worlds.
Part 2 so builds on top of Part 1 in the most incredible ways possible. It has everything you could want from a Harry Potter film and its not only the end of the series but also a huge part of my childhood. The acting was so tremendous, Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson really gave it their best this time and I know they'll miss it as much as we will, Alan Rickman show true emotion in his role as Snape and Ralph Fiennes is such a brilliant Voldermort overall the acting was tremendous, David Yates really shows how great a director he really can be in this final film, J.K. Rowling really is fabulous author, the plot magnificently written, the score is wonderful, the special effects are brilliant, the sets are so well made, the cinematographer is breathtaking, the editing is impressive, the ending is excellent and their really is a sense of honest emotion in this film. 
Harry Potter is a one-of-a-kind fantasy series: Its a story about life, bravery, friendship, conquering your fears, what you can do if you put your mind to it and growing up. I guess that's why the series is so popular and that it will always stay in hearts forever.
