And so it comes to this. The end of the Harry Potter franchise, which has lasted 10 years, over 8 films, and as the curtain comes down, they've saved the best till last. It's very operatic in scale and tone, and it whizzes by at breakneck speed, and it's a fitting end to an enjoyable franchise. It starts off from where Part 1 ended last year. Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) getting the Elder Wand from the grave of Dumbledore (Michael Gambon). Meanwhile, Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson) break into the vault of Bellatrix Lestrange (Helena Bonham Carter) at Gringott's Bank to get the a cup, which is one of the Horcruxes to be destroyed to defeat Voldemort. Then they have to get into Hogwarts, now run with an iron fist by Snape (Alan Rickman), to find a tiara which has to be destroyed too. Voldemort has assembled an army to bring down Hogwarts and kill Harry Potter, but our hero isn't defeated yet, although he learns that he was always destined to die, no matter what, as a bit of Voldemort has been in him from when he killed Harry's parents. It's a dark film but there is relief by the end, that there's no more threats to Harry. You've come to care and be entertained by these characters over the last 10 years, we've watched them go through childhood to adulthood. The final showdown between Harry and Voldemort is well worth waiting for. It is the shortest film of the series, you would have thought they would have gone all out with this one though.

Summary: Movie should have been longer and in 2D

Plot: The film hinges on the final battle between death eaters and other wizards. Hogwarts is the center of all action. Death and destruction is no longer discussed in background. You literally see the beautiful castle, Hogsmeade and Gringotts being ripped apart and people die. Let me stop with that.

Special Effects: The film has been shot in 3D and, as with its prequels, the final episode boots really good CGI. Apparations, flying broomsticks, dragons, giants, slithering snakes, magic - everything is thrown at the audience in the two hour running time of the movie. And its all so beautifully interwoven that you end up applauding their physics rather than cringe thinking about their improbability.

Cast: The main stars need no introduction. I guess this series was blessed, for they managed to complete production of eight movies with almost the same cast as they began. So in order to review the casting I need to go back in time - I guess it is unnecessary. I do not think we are going to get a more fitting description of Harry or Ron or Hermione. The only gripe is that we get to see less of some favorite characters (like Hagrid for example).

Performance: The lead characters have done good. Not just in this movie but the entire series. Kudos to the kids who dared to spend the most crucial years of their lives to entertain us (yeah they definitely got a handsome pay in return) and have been keen to learn from day one to get their acting skills honed. Of the others I would always rate Alan Rickman's portrayal of the complex character of Snape as a cut above the rest - it was like a character written in the book come alive. Evanna Lynch also cast her character (of Luna Lovegood) with charm. Helena Bonham Carter will forever be remembered as the sneering Bellatrix Lestrange.

Read the full review at http://blog.nrajesh.com/review-deathly-hallows-2

Dramatic, emotional, action-packed and a wonderful and dignified ending to this epic story. Splitting the book into two films paid off, especially for fans of the books, such as myself and I found I enjoyed it more than any of it's predecessors as much of it stayed loyal to the books and I do feel it did justice to important character deaths, most notably the suprisingly violent death of Severus Snape (played fantastically by Alan Rickman) which left me feeling I was no longer watching a children's film, but something much darker and grittier. This particular scene was for me the highlight of the film, wonderfully portrayed and left me, as expected, in tears, almost to rival the written version. To fans of the films only it is a fantastic retelling and one could barely hope for more, except for perhaps a better ageing effect in the final scene, though still this did not distract from the overall feel of the film. For the hard to please fans of the books (i.e. myself) this adaptation was at least acceptable (unlike Prisoner of Azkaban for example) and in many parts an honourable ending to this deeply loved story.

Best film in the Harry Potter series, and if you knew me you'd know I don't say that lightly.  

First, the not so good - could it stand alone as a film by itself, no.  But then again it's not meant to, so not complaining.  Is it me or did it seem that Dumbledore was portrayed as a horrible bastard who sold poor Harry down the river?  A lamb to slaughter as Snape so aptly puts it.  Why did they not better explain the Elder Wand and how it passes from master to master, because it's imperative people understand that Harry does not kill Voldemort, ultimately, Voldemort kills himself and that doesn't come across.

Now the good - Alan Rickman!!  Dude, you are my hero.  I was disgusted when he was killed off and dismissed in the book.  And while the death of Snape was pretty faithful to the book, Rickman's acting literally stole the story away from Harry in those moments.  He died a hero, as he should have.  The scenes in the penseive were awesome.  They were enough to let you understand how much he loved Lily but not so much that you resented James Potter.  Kudos.

Soooooo glad they didn't attempt to explain the Deathly Hallows, too time consuming.  The horcruxes were far more important.  Ron and Hermione... Perfect.  Not too long or sappy.  Yay!

Neville, you go!!  Loved the speech he gave after Harry 'died'. Just shows how far that character has come.  

Finally, although some didn't like it, I loved that it ended with Harry and Voldemort standing alone, as it began.

Oh, and 'not my daughter you bitch!!!'. 

Superb film, great acting, amazing effects.

Thank you Jo for sharing your world with us.

Few films come along with the weight of expectation and excitement than the Harry Potter films and none come higher or heavier than the final film of the series. Those who were never seduced by the source material or by the films themselves will never understand just how much Potter means to its fans and for ten years they (we)have been treated to seven films that each have delivered consistent quality. Even from the point of view of analysing the strength and faithfulness of the adaptations, we as fans have few things to really complain about. But Deathly Hallows Part 2 is different because it is the concluding part of a single large story split into 2 films, therefore it doesn't really have any excuse not to deliver. It isn't perfect but it comes damn close but none the less as finales go it's really hard to top.

Contrasted with all previous films, DH Part 2 feels the most confident in its design and execution. Such is the accuracy and assurance of how Yates has delivered the emotional punches that DH Part 2 easily feels the most confident. It benefits from being part 2 of a single film by diving head first into the action and it's fast and generally perfect pace keeps the film feeling constantly thrilling. Yet it does slow down appropriately and includes small but outstanding scenes with John Hurt's Ollivander, Warwick Davis' Griphook and Ciaran Hinds' Aberforth Dumbledore just to name a few. It's to Yates' credit that these small moments do stand out most because the action set pieces and glorious spectacle is spellbinding throughout; from the infiltration of Gringott's to the apocalypse on the Hogwart's Courtyard.   

As said above, Yates seems to have a firm idea on how to deliver scenes that should draw strong emotion and it's always been his greatest strength throughout each film. DH Part 2 is filled with arguably the best moments of the whole series; cold horror as Voldemort walks through a bloody slaughter, elation and suspense as the defenses of Hogwarts are raised. However Yates and his composer, Alexander Desplat should take a bow alone for the beautiful and heartbreaking moments as the truth of Snape is revealed and Harry's pivotal trip into the Forest. It's these grand and pivotal moments that fans have waited since 2007 to see on screen and Yates delivers them to perfection.

However the films only real flaw is that it doesn't really slow down enough. There is a real sense that not much attention is given to the secondary characters, granted not always the most important, but characters who none the less have been there all along the last 10 years who you feel should get a good send off. Some you can relegate yes but to essentially ignore most of the Weasley's? Yates shows ill judgement here as well as reducing the pivotal Battle of Hogwart's to the background as well. His approach to focus primarily on Harry, Ron, Hermione and Voldemort is understandable and it does pay dividends but you do feel that more could have been delivered here because what's teased is breathtaking.

The end is finally here as Harry and Voldemort Square up to each other for one more earth shaking Duel, no more life-lines, no more missed chances, this is the deciding Scrap of the fate of all Hogwarts.
Once again directed by David Yate's the film bring's to light the more chilling and hostile concept's of the Wizarding War, throughout the film there are a number of character's that the viewer's see killed ( not naming names) and not only that but Hogwart's is totally demolished in the fight.
Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson's acting has vast improved over the year's and this film is really where they are at their best.  Part 2 is Powerful, Dark and Moving, a number of character's have been able to get their teeth into the real acting in this one and the character of Snape played by Alan Rickman is one of these. people. 
For fan's  like myself who have grown up with the series, read the books and watched the films over the course of their childhood, this is an end of an era, one which holds very happy memories for many people. The HP series will alway's remain a big part of those people's live's, and while now the series is finished those people will alway's look back and remember reading about  Ron Weasley and how he become Obsessed with Ramilda Vane, Hermione Granger and her facination with books and Harry Potter of whom the books and films  recklessly follow through his year's at Hogwarts.
It's these characters, along with Hagrid, McGonnigal, Snape and Sirius Black that will alway's be remembered by the fans. 10 year's has been an awfully long wait for such a brilliant series to reach it's  thrilling end but now as the world enter's the aftermath of the most Successful franchise in the world it's clear to see that what was once expected to be a small family film (Philospher's Stone ) has turned into something quite Epic; credit to the directors and all the cast and crew and most of all a thank you to Mrs JK.Rowling.

I've been to see a few summer films this year 2 of them I liked the most and that's Harry Potter and Super  8. Let's start with Harry Potter.
Having sensed Voldemort thinking of his Horcrux and Hogwarts through their connection, Harry tells Ron and Hermione that they have to go there and destroy it before Voldemort can get to it, adding that Voldemort seems to be getting more fragile and afraid with each Horcrux destroyed. They Apparate to Hogsmeade, but immediately trigger Caterwauling alarms set up by Death Eaters, who were waiting for Harry. The trio are almost captured, but Aberforth Dumbledore gets them safely into his home and berates them for coming to the village. 
Harry discovers that it was Aberforth who has been watching them through the mirror shard and the one who sent Dobby to rescue them after seeing the two-way mirror hung up on the wall. Aberforth provides them with food and advises them to give up on their mission, go into hiding and save themselves. Harry said that he trusts Albus Dumbledore's judgement that the task has to be seen through no matter what, but Aberforth insists that Albus had left them a suicide mission and it was hopeless. The nice thing about the Potter films is that the hero is not especially attractive, clever, gifted or likeable. He is lucky, protected and helped a lot. His virtues are bravery, resourcefulness, focus and loyalty. It's in these last films that I appreciated this set of characteristics most. And these are the ones that win the day. As such. the films could have been more moving than they were. I suspect being set in magic land probably made that difficult but I also wonder whether Daniel Ratcliffe would have been the actor to convey this. I await his future films with interest. To be fair, the actor does mighty well in conveying the concentration, restless anxiety, anger and soul-searching his character's predicament demands and although the films are children's films, the cast treat them seriously and the exotic and enjoyable performances from a whole host of top actors serve as great counterpoint to Potter's 'real' struggle.

Well, It's all over. The last chapter of a franchise of eight films that have enchanted people of every ages, in every part of the world, and have earned 7 billion dollars world wide and have become the highest-grossing franchise of all times, even beating out Star Wars and James Bond, who held the number one position before Harry Potter. I personaly have been more interested in the books rather than the films. But the facts is that's it's not going to be any other Harry Potter films, and now I feel the magic is gone, and there's no need to watch the movies or read the books again. It's a lot like graduating day, and I have to admit, I feld a tear during the last scene of this final chapter.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows part two, follows where the last film ended, when Lord Voldemort took the Elder Wand from Dumbledore's grave. Our heroes Harry, Ron and Hermione is safe in a house at the beach where Ron's brother Bill and his wife Fleur Delacour lives. They just escaped from Malfoy's house with both Griphook and Olivander. Our heroes discuss with Griphook how to break into Bellatrix Lestrange's Gringotts vault to find one of Voldemort's horcruxes. After a nearly failed mission in the bank, our hero's manage to escape on a dragon. But soon after, another problem occurs, Harry gets into Voldemort's mind once more and watch his anger of how any got to know his biggest secret. Harry who already have destroyed five of seven gets finally to know where the final unknown horcrux is. And then our hero's have no other choice than to go back to Hogwards where Voldemort's right hand Severus Snape is in charge. And a fight between the good and evil, but first Harry have to get rid of his own demons first.

My opinion about this last chapter is that it's a good film with spectacular special effects, but some times it's can be to much show off, just to show what the animators can do developing new forms of special effects. Some of the scenes didn't need that much, it could easily gone for the more easy organic solutions. Most director these days don't see the magic of the characters, it's acting which is the real magic. It's not needed, this facade that has haunted this movie since the fifth part, when the death eaters starts to flying in black smoke and all the other starts to do the same. An example of where special effects have taken attention from the acting. But I also have positive feedback about the special effects, In this film the amazing battle sequence is beyond what I imagined.

What did I think about the adaptation? Well I think it was good. The book contains many clues, that is spread through the whole series. The problem is you can't expect the audience to keep tracks of so many clues, and flashback wouldn't have worked either. So I'm surprised how they where able to paste in the clues, but it might feel like some of the solutions comes right of the thin air. One thing I specially liked about this film, was that the director knew the fact that this was the final film, and the fact that they used elements and places from the earlier films, and they have manage to take me back to it as it was before, every tiny little details, which brings a tear to my eyes.

My Conclusion of this very final film. it's that tells us all we need to know and there's nothing more to be told, there's no need for any sequels. It's over. Period. It's the whole conclusion of the entire series. combines old and new, goes back in time. The epic fight, both physical and psychological, and it's a movie that it's impossible to don't like. So I throw my hat in the air and give it a Thumbs up!

that's my cat's thoughts on the movie.  I can't add much more except to say I didn't think much of this.  I'm not a fan of Harry Potter books or films.  The stories are full of arbitrary deus ex magica solutions. I also believe the series promotes and justifies xenophobia, hatred and prejudice. Why is Voldemort bad? Because he is evil! Why is Harry Potter a hero? Because he was born to be one! It's probably silly of me to point out the tautological flaws in a fantasy flick, but the obvious heirarchical ranking of everything and everybody sure did irk me. Like the Slytherins getting herded into the dungeon, or how the sorting hat could have put him in Slytherin, but Harry really wanted Griffindor, because you know Griffindor is just  better. I was also distrubed by the greedy banker dwarves, and how similar they  looked to anti Jewish propaganda cartoons used by the Nazis and others looking for someone to hate. Elder's of Zion anyone?

I want to get it out of the way right now that my theater's sound was god awful. I could barely hear anything and the action was muffled. I can proudly say my 5.1 Surround Sound system at home is 100x better than the theater's. I'm only saying this because the action scenes were devoid of any excitement.

Now to this movie. I didn't read the books and I don't think anyone watching these movies should have to if they just want to sit back and enjoy themselves. It seems the film makers tailor-made the last 4 movies only for the book-readers. Otherwise it's just plot-holes, boring expositional dialogue, and consequence-free action(one character's death who shall not be named was done horribly!). My GOD the plot-holes are endless! Don't even get me started on the half-assed romance sub-plots.

In the end, this movie failed because it only appeals to fans of the books and leaves everyone else out to dry. If you're thinking of watching the whole series from the beginning, stop after film 4.
